An interesting side effect of the superconductor is the production of a powerful magnetic field that can produce a levitating effect, called the Meissner Effect, which some hope to translate into the hovering vehicles that were once nothing more than the dreams of science-fiction fans.
TEXT.French: [TAB]La supraconductivité est une propriété de certains métaux et céramiques, qui leur permet de conduire l'électricité sans aucune résistance. Cette supraconductivité n'apparaît qu'à des températures extrêmement froides, ce qui signifie que leur création exige une connaissance approfondie des techniques de basse température.[PARAGRAPH:2]Depuis sa découverte, le supraconducteur a trouvé son application dans les aimants à haute puissance, les IRM (Imagerie à résonance magnétique) et les appareils de stockage d'énergie qui n'auraient jamais pu exister sans ses propriétés uniques. Un des effets secondaires intéressants du supraconducteur est la production d'un puissant champ magnétique capable de produire un effet de lévitation, appelé effet Meissner, que certains espèrent pouvoir utiliser pour créer les véhicules flottants qui jadis n'existaient que les rêves des fans de science-fiction.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Supraleitfähigkeit ist eine Eigenschaft bestimmter Metalle und Keramikstoffe, die Strom ohne jeglichen Widerstand leiten. Diese Supraleitfähigkeit tritt nur bei extrem niedrigen Temperaturen auf, d. h. ihre Herstellung erfordert genaue Kenntnisse entsprechender Techniken.[PARAGRAPH:2]Seit ihrer Entdeckung werden Supraleiter in Hochleistungsmagneten, MRTs (Magnetresonanztomographien) und Stromspeichergeräten eingesetzt, die ohne deren einzigartige Eigenschaften niemals denkbar wären. Ein interessanter Nebeneffekt des Supraleiters ist die Erzeugung eines starken Magnetfelds, das einen Schwebeeffekt, Meißner-Effekt genannt, verursachen kann, den manche bei Schwebefahrzeugen einsetzen möchten, die einst nur in der Phantasie der Science-Fiction-Fans existierten.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]La superconduttività è la proprietà di alcuni metalli e ceramiche di condurre elettricità senza alcuna resistenza. La superconduttività compare solo a temperature molto basse, il che significa che la loro creazione implica una profonda conoscenza di tecniche produttive alle basse temperature.[PARAGRAPH:2]Dalla loro scoperta, i superconduttori hanno trovato impiego in magneti ad alto potenziale, MRI (apparecchi di imaging con risonanza magnetica) e in accumulatori, e non sarebbe stato possibile crearli senza le loro proprietà particolari. Un interessante effetto collaterale dei superconduttori è la produzione di un potente campo magnetico in grado di creare un effetto di levitazione, chiamato Effetto Meissner, che molti sperano di convertire per la creazione di veicoli in grado di volare a punto fisso, cosa che una volta era solo un sogno degli appassionati di fantascienza.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]La superconductividad es la propiedad de ciertos materiales metálicos y cerámicos que les permite conducir la electricidad sin ofrecer prácticamente ninguna resistencia. Esta característica solo se manifiesta a temperaturas muy bajas, lo que significa que la creación de estos materiales exige un profundo conocimiento de crio-técnicas.[PARAGRAPH:2]Desde su descubrimiento, los superconductores se han utilizado en la construcción de imanes de gran potencia, MRI (imágenes por resonancia magnética) y dispositivos de almacenamiento de energía que hasta entonces nunca habían sido posibles. Un interesante efecto secundario de la superconducción es la producción de potentes campos magnéticos que generan un efecto de levitación (llamado el efecto Meissner). Existen proyectos para emplear este efecto en la propiedad de vehículos flotantes como los que hasta hace poco eran patrimonio exclusivo de la ciencia-ficción.

TEXT.English: [TAB]An artist is a person engaged in one or more of any of a broad spectrum of activities related to creating art, practicing the arts, and/or demonstrating an art. The common usage in both everyday speech and academic discourse is a practitioner in the visual arts only. The term is often used in the entertainment business, especially in a business context, for musicians and other performers (less often for actors). "Artiste" (the French for artist) is a variant used in English only in this context. Use of the term to describe writers, for example, is certainly valid, but less common, and mostly restricted to contexts like criticism.

[TAB]Citizenship is the status of a person recognized under the custom or law of a state that bestows on that person (called a citizen) the rights and the duties of citizenship. That may include the right to vote, work and live in the country, the right to return to the country, the right to own real estate, legal protections against the country's government, and protection through the military or diplomacy. A citizen may also be subject to certain duties, such as a duty to follow the country's law, to pay taxes, or to serve in the military. A person may have multiple citizenships and a person who does not have citizenship of any state is said to be stateless. Nationality is often used as a synonym for citizenship in English - notably in international law - although the term is sometimes understood as denoting a person's membership of a nation (a large ethnic group). In some countries, e.g. the United States, the United Kingdom, nationality and citizenship can have different meanings.

[TAB]An engineer is a professional practitioner of engineering, concerned with applying scientific knowledge, mathematics, and ingenuity to develop solutions for technical, societal and commercial problems. Engineers design materials, structures, and systems while considering the limitations imposed by practicality, regulation, safety, and cost.[PARAGRAPH:1]The work of engineers forms the link between scientific discoveries and their subsequent applications to human needs and quality of life.

The common usage in both everyday speech and academic discourse is a practitioner in the visual arts only. The term is often used in the entertainment business, especially in a business context, for musicians and other performers (less often for actors). "Artiste" (the French for artist) is a variant used in English only in this context. Use of the term to describe writers, for example, is certainly valid, but less common, and mostly restricted to contexts like criticism.

Engineers design materials, structures, and systems while considering the limitations imposed by practicality, regulation, safety, and cost.[PARAGRAPH:1]The work of engineers forms the link between scientific discoveries and their subsequent applications to human needs and quality of life.

[TAB]A general, without prefix or suffix (and sometimes referred to informally as a "full general"), is usually the most senior type of general, above lieutenant general and directly below field marshal. Usually it is the most senior peacetime rank, with more senior ranks (for example, field marshal, air chief marshal, fleet admiral) being used only in wartime, or as honorary titles.[PARAGRAPH:1]In some armies, however, the rank of captain general, general of the army, army general or colonel general occupied or occupies this position. Depending on circumstances and the army in question, these ranks may be considered to be equivalent to a "full" general or to a field marshal.[PARAGRAPH:1]The rank of general came about as a "captain-general", the captain of an army in general (i.e., the whole army). The rank of captain-general began appearing around the time of the organisation of professional armies in the 17th century. In most countries "captain-general" contracted to just "general".

[TAB]A merchant is a businessperson who trades in commodities produced by others, in order to earn a profit. The status of the merchant has varied during different periods of history and amongst different societies. Merchants have often been the subject of works of art.[PARAGRAPH:1]A merchant class characterizes many pre-modern societies. Its status can range from high (the members even eventually achieving titles such as that of Merchant Prince or Nabob) to low, as in Chinese culture, owing to the presumed distastefulness of profiting from "mere" trade rather than from labor or the labor of others as in agriculture and craftsmanship.[PARAGRAPH:1]In the Greco-Roman world merchants typically did not have high social status, though they may have enjoyed great wealth, and there were exceptions, such as in Syria and Palestine in late antiquity, where merchants did have a high social position.[PARAGRAPH:1]Medieval attitudes toward merchants in the West were strongly influenced by criticism of their activities by the Christian church, which closely associated their activities with the sin of usury.[PARAGRAPH:1]From around 1300 to the 1800s a large number of European Chartered and Merchant Companies were established to utilize international trading opportunities, for instance the Company of Merchant Adventurers of London, Chartered in 1407.

[TAB]A priest is a person authorized to perform the sacred rituals of a religion, especially as a mediatory agent between humans and one or more deities. They also have the authority or power to administer religious rites; in particular, rites of sacrifice to, and propitiation of, a deity or deities. Their office or position is the priesthood, a term which also may apply to such persons collectively.[PARAGRAPH:1]Priests have existed since the earliest of times and in the simplest societies, most likely as a result of agricultural surplus and consequent social stratification. The necessity to read sacred texts and keep temple or church records helped foster literacy in many early societies. Priests exist in many religions today, such as all or some branches of Judaism, Christianity, Shintoism, Hinduism. They are generally regarded as having positive contact with the deity or deities of the religion to which they subscribe, often interpreting the meaning of events and performing the rituals of the religion. There is no common definition of the duties of priesthood between faiths; but generally it includes mediating the relationship between one's congregation, worshippers, and other members of the religious body, and its deity or deities, and administering religious rituals and rites. These often include blessing worshipers with prayers of joy at marriages, after a birth, and at consecrations, teaching the wisdom and dogma of the faith at any regular worship service, and mediating and easing the experience of grief and death at funerals - maintaining a spiritual connection to the afterlife in faiths where such a concept exists. Administering religious building grounds and office affairs and papers, including any religious library or collection of sacred texts, is also commonly a responsibility - for example, the modern term for clerical duties in a secular office refers originally to the duties of a cleric. The question of which religions have a "priest" depends on how the titles of leaders are used or translated into English. In some cases, leaders are more like those that other believers will often turn for advice on spiritual matters, and less of a "person authorized to perform the sacred rituals" For example, clergy in Roman Catholicism and Orthodox Christianity are priests, but in Protestant Christianity they are typically minister and pastor. The terms priest and priestess are sufficiently generic that they may be used in an anthropological sense to describe the religious mediators of an unknown or otherwise unspecified religion.[PARAGRAPH:1]In many religions, being a priest or priestess is a full-time position, ruling out any other career. Many Christian priests and pastors choose or are mandated to dedicate themselves to their churches and receive their living directly from their churches. In other cases it is a part-time role. For example in the early history of Iceland the chieftains were titled goði, a word meaning "priest". As seen in the saga of Hrafnkell Freysgoði, however, being a priest consisted merely of offering periodic sacrifices to the Norse gods and goddesses; it was not a full-time role, nor did it involve ordination.[PARAGRAPH:1]In some religions, being a priest or priestess is by human election or human choice. In Judaism the priesthood is inherited in familial lines.

[TAB]A scientist, in a broad sense, is one engaging in a systematic activity to acquire knowledge. In a more restricted sense, a scientist may refer to an individual who uses the scientific method. The person may be an expert in one or more areas of science. This article focuses on the more restricted use of the word. Scientists perform research toward a more comprehensive understanding of nature, including physical, mathematical and social realms.[PARAGRAPH:1]Philosophy can be seen as a distinct activity and which many consider not to be a science. It is aimed towards a more comprehensive understanding of intangible aspects of reality and experience that cannot be physically measured.[PARAGRAPH:1]Scientists are also distinct from engineers, those who design, build and maintain devices for particular situations. When science is done with a goal toward practical utility, it is called applied science. An applied scientist may not be designing something in particular, but rather is conducting research with the aim of developing new technologies and practical methods. When science is done with an inclusion of intangible aspects of reality it is called natural philosophy.

[TAB]Espionage is often part of an institutional effort by a government or commercial concern. However, the term is generally associated with state spying on potential or actual enemies primarily for military purposes. Spying involving corporations is known as industrial espionage.[PARAGRAPH:1]One of the most effective ways to gather data and information about the enemy (or potential enemy) is by infiltrating the enemy's ranks. This is the job of the spy (espionage agent). Spies can bring back all sorts of information concerning the size and strength of an enemy army. They can also find dissidents within the enemy's forces and influence them to defect. In times of crisis, spies can also be used to steal technology and to sabotage the enemy in various ways. Counterintelligence operatives can feed false information to enemy spies, protecting important domestic secrets, and preventing attempts at subversion. Nearly every country has very strict laws concerning espionage, and the penalty for being caught is often severe. However, the benefits that can be gained through espionage are generally great enough that most governments and many large corporations make use of it to varying degrees.
[TAB]A statesman is usually a politician, diplomat or other notable public figure who has had a long and respected career at the national or international level.

[TAB]A merchant is a businessperson who trades in commodities produced by others, in order to earn a profit. The status of the merchant has varied during different periods of history and amongst different societies. Merchants have often been the subject of works of art.[PARAGRAPH:1]A merchant class characterizes many pre-modern societies. Its status can range from high (the members even eventually achieving titles such as that of Merchant Prince or Nabob) to low, as in Chinese culture, owing to the presumed distastefulness of profiting from "mere" trade rather than from labor or the labor of others as in agriculture and craftsmanship.[PARAGRAPH:1]In the Greco-Roman world merchants typically did not have high social status, though they may have enjoyed great wealth, and there were exceptions, such as in Syria and Palestine in late antiquity, where merchants did have a high social position.[PARAGRAPH:1]Medieval attitudes toward merchants in the West were strongly influenced by criticism of their activities by the Christian church, which closely associated their activities with the sin of usury.[PARAGRAPH:1]From around 1300 to the 1800s a large number of European Chartered and Merchant Companies were established to utilize international trading opportunities, for instance the Company of Merchant Adventurers of London, Chartered in 1407.

[TAB]A priest is a person authorized to perform the sacred rituals of a religion, especially as a mediatory agent between humans and one or more deities. They also have the authority or power to administer religious rites; in particular, rites of sacrifice to, and propitiation of, a deity or deities. Their office or position is the priesthood, a term which also may apply to such persons collectively.[PARAGRAPH:1]Priests have existed since the earliest of times and in the simplest societies, most likely as a result of agricultural surplus and consequent social stratification. The necessity to read sacred texts and keep temple or church records helped foster literacy in many early societies. Priests exist in many religions today, such as all or some branches of Judaism, Christianity, Shintoism, Hinduism. They are generally regarded as having positive contact with the deity or deities of the religion to which they subscribe, often interpreting the meaning of events and performing the rituals of the religion. There is no common definition of the duties of priesthood between faiths; but generally it includes mediating the relationship between one's congregation, worshippers, and other members of the religious body, and its deity or deities, and administering religious rituals and rites. These often include blessing worshipers with prayers of joy at marriages, after a birth, and at consecrations, teaching the wisdom and dogma of the faith at any regular worship service, and mediating and easing the experience of grief and death at funerals - maintaining a spiritual connection to the afterlife in faiths where such a concept exists. Administering religious building grounds and office affairs and papers, including any religious library or collection of sacred texts, is also commonly a responsibility - for example, the modern term for clerical duties in a secular office refers originally to the duties of a cleric. The question of which religions have a "priest" depends on how the titles of leaders are used or translated into English. In some cases, leaders are more like those that other believers will often turn for advice on spiritual matters, and less of a "person authorized to perform the sacred rituals" For example, clergy in Roman Catholicism and Orthodox Christianity are priests, but in Protestant Christianity they are typically minister and pastor. The terms priest and priestess are sufficiently generic that they may be used in an anthropological sense to describe the religious mediators of an unknown or otherwise unspecified religion.[PARAGRAPH:1]In many religions, being a priest or priestess is a full-time position, ruling out any other career. Many Christian priests and pastors choose or are mandated to dedicate themselves to their churches and receive their living directly from their churches. In other cases it is a part-time role. For example in the early history of Iceland the chieftains were titled goði, a word meaning "priest". As seen in the saga of Hrafnkell Freysgoði, however, being a priest consisted merely of offering periodic sacrifices to the Norse gods and goddesses; it was not a full-time role, nor did it involve ordination.[PARAGRAPH:1]In some religions, being a priest or priestess is by human election or human choice. In Judaism the priesthood is inherited in familial lines.

[TAB]A scientist, in a broad sense, is one engaging in a systematic activity to acquire knowledge. In a more restricted sense, a scientist may refer to an individual who uses the scientific method. The person may be an expert in one or more areas of science. This article focuses on the more restricted use of the word. Scientists perform research toward a more comprehensive understanding of nature, including physical, mathematical and social realms.[PARAGRAPH:1]Philosophy can be seen as a distinct activity and which many consider not to be a science. It is aimed towards a more comprehensive understanding of intangible aspects of reality and experience that cannot be physically measured.[PARAGRAPH:1]Scientists are also distinct from engineers, those who design, build and maintain devices for particular situations. When science is done with a goal toward practical utility, it is called applied science. An applied scientist may not be designing something in particular, but rather is conducting research with the aim of developing new technologies and practical methods. When science is done with an inclusion of intangible aspects of reality it is called natural philosophy.

[TAB]Though laws and systems vary, as property, slaves may be bought and sold. Slaves can be held from the time of their capture, purchase or birth, and deprived of the right to leave, to refuse to work, or to demand compensation. Historically, slavery was institutionally recognized by most societies; in more recent times, slavery has been outlawed in all countries, but it continues through the practices of debt bondage, serfdom, domestic servants kept in captivity, certain adoptions in which children are forced to work as slaves, child soldiers, and forced marriage. Slavery is officially illegal in all countries, but there are still an estimated 20 million to 36 million slaves worldwide. Mauritania was the last jurisdiction to officially outlaw slavery (in 1981/2007), but about 10% to 20% of its population is estimated to live in slavery.[PARAGRAPH:1]Slavery has existed before written history and has existed in many cultures. Most slaves today are debt slaves, largely in South Asia, who are under debt bondage incurred by lenders, sometimes even for generations. Human trafficking is primarily used for forcing women and children into sex industries.
[TAB]A statesman is usually a politician, diplomat or other notable public figure who has had a long and respected career at the national or international level.

[H1]Conditional Spawns[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Certain civilizations in Dawn of Civilization only spawn when the right conditions are met. These civilizations are Byzantium, Italy, the Ottomans, Thailand, Iran, and Mexico. Their requirements are listed below: [NEWLINE][BOLD]Byzantium:[\BOLD] [ICON_BULLET]Greece has to be dead [ICON_BULLET]Rome has to be alive [ICON_BULLET]If Rome is human controlled, the Byzantine spawn can be prevented by having a Solid stability [NEWLINE][BOLD]Italy:[\BOLD] [ICON_BULLET]Rome has to be dead [NEWLINE][BOLD]Ottomans:[\BOLD] [ICON_BULLET]Always spawns if any city in their birth area is human controlled [ICON_BULLET]Does not spawn if the Turks never conquer a city in Asia west of Persia [NEWLINE][BOLD]Thailand:[\BOLD] [ICON_BULLET]Always spawns if the Khmer are dead [ICON_BULLET]Also spawns if the Khmer stability is Shaky or lower [ICON_BULLET]If the human player controls the Khmer, Shaky stability is sufficient to prevent the Thai spawn [NEWLINE][BOLD]Iran:[\BOLD] [ICON_BULLET]Persia has to be dead [NEWLINE][BOLD]Mexico:[\BOLD] [ICON_BULLET]Aztecs have to be dead[PARAGRAPH:2]The civilizations of Argentina, Mexico, Colombia, Brazil, and Canada are considered conditional independence spawns. Their spawn is canceled if all players that control any city in their birth area have Solid stability.

[H1]Congresses[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Congresses in Rhye's and Fall represent the phenomenon of informal institutionalization of international politics that began during the 19th century. This includes the idea of the balance of power which manifested itself in the Congress of Vienna and the Concert of Europe, but also international conferences on territorial claims such as the Berlin Congress. They also represent other diplomatic exchanges of territory like the Louisiana Purchase.[PARAGRAPH:2]Congresses take place as soon as the first civilization discovers Nationalism and regularly occur every 15 turns. The ten most powerful civilizations of the world will be invited, and each of them can either claim a city or request to found a colony on unsettled territory. If the majority of civilizations agrees, the request is granted and the city will change hands or a settler will be created on the demanded empty spot. While the human player can decide on claims by voting YES, NO or ABSTAIN, the AI will make its own decisions based on a variety of factors. These include the legitimacy of the claim (e.g. if the claimed city is historical for the civilization or if it already has culture there), the relationship to the demanding and controlling civilizations, including their own interest in the city.[PARAGRAPH:2]If a player claim was considered legitimate by an AI, but not granted because of insufficient relations, or if a player city has been granted to another civilization by the AI, the player can choose a number of options to influence the vote of AI civilizations in their favor. This can happen either through bribery (offering gold) or manipulation (expending espionage points). The player can spend varying amounts of both resources depending on how much they consider influencing their votes necessary. Another way to influence the AI is by agreeing to their own claims in the same congress - or at least avoiding to vote against them![PARAGRAPH:2]If all attempts fail and the congress still gives away one of your cities, you still have the opportunity to refuse handing it over. But be careful, this may cause some of the civilizations that agreed to the request to go to war over your contempt for their decision! The more votes were in favor of reassigning the city, the likelier an individual civilization is to go to war.[PARAGRAPH:2]Congresses are disrupted by global wars, under which different rules apply. A global war takes place when at least half the military power of the world is at war with each other. During these times, no congresses occur because the world is settling its differences on the battlefield instead of the negotiation table. However, when such a global war ends (by the main belligerents agreeing to peace), peace is enforced on all belligerents and a new congress is called to restore order after the war. Such a congress differs from normal congresses in that only belligerents are invited, that only civilizations on the winning side are allowed to make demands, and that it is impossible to request colonizing free territory. Civilizations that have lost the war still can vote on all claims, however. Congresses completely come to an end when the United Nations are built because their formalized approach to multilateral diplomacy makes congresses obsolete. [NEWLINE]If you are familiar with Congresses from Rhye's and Fall, you will notice multiple significant changes and improvements over the previous system, some of which have already been mentioned: [ICON_BULLET]In addition to periodic congresses, congresses can also occur after global wars [ICON_BULLET]Participants can also request to settle free territory [ICON_BULLET]A streamlined interaction process so that the entire congress can be resolved in one turn [ICON_BULLET]Significant improvements in computation times [ICON_BULLET]When voting on a claim, the camera centers on the plot or city in question [ICON_BULLET]The option to influence a civilization's decision is only offered when there is actually a chance of success [ICON_BULLET]Attempts to influence a decision are now specific to a certain claim and can be used both to achieve agreement to an own claim and disagreement with a claim on your own cities [ICON_BULLET]There is no limit on how many civilizations can be attempted to be influenced during the same Congress [ICON_BULLET]In addition to bribery by offering gold, votes can also be manipulated by expending espionage [ICON_BULLET]More sophisticated AI decisionmaking: it now takes the legitimacy of the claim, its relations to the claimant and owner, and its own interest in the city into account [ICON_BULLET]More global AI decisionmaking: your own voting behavior influences how the AI treats your claims and the claims against you, global opinion influences how likely AIs are to go to war over a refused claim [ICON_BULLET]No more multiple assignments during the same Congress: if more than one civilization have successfully claimed the same city, it goes to the civilization that received the most votes in favor

[H1]Continents, Countries and Unique Historical Victories[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Rhye has split the World Map into separate continents. No longer will a wonder built in China have an effect on a city in South Africa. With this magic, Rhye also further subdivided the world into countries, even assigning historically accurate city names to individual tiles. These names will be your guide for the UHVs. For most of the territory UHVs (Control the Balkans, Control Mesopotamia, etc.) you will be required to control up to 3 cities in the area. Rome is the most stringent, requiring 2 cities in Iberia, 3 cities in Gaul, 1 city in Britain, 2 cities in Africa, 4 cities in Greece and Byzantium and 2 cities in Egypt.[PARAGRAPH:2]In Dawn of Civilization, the regions that pertain to your UHV are shown in the tile tooltip when hovering over the relevant tiles.
TEXT.French: [H1]Continents, pays et victoires historiques uniques[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Rhye a divisé le monde en continents séparés. Une merveille construite en Chine n'aura donc plus aucun effet sur une ville en Afrique du Sud. Avec sa magie, Rhye a continué de diviser le monde pour créer des pays et a même attribué à des cases des noms de villes historiquement exacts. Ces noms vous serviront de repère pour remporter les victoires historiques uniques (VHU). Pour la plupart des VHU de territoire (Contrôler les Balkans, Contrôler la Mésopotamie, etc.), vous devrez contrôler jusqu'à trois villes dans la zone. C'est avec Rome qu'il sera le plus difficile d'y parvenir, car vous devrez contrôler trois villes en Ibérie, trois en France, trois en Afrique du Nord, deux en Allemagne, une en Angleterre et trois en Italie.
TEXT.German: [H1]Kontinente, Länder und Einzigartige Historische Siege[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Rhye hat die Weltkarte in separate Kontinente aufgeteilt, somit hat ein in China errichtetes Wunder nun keine Auswirkungen mehr auf eine Stadt in Südafrika. Darüber hinaus weist die Karte natürlich auch Länder aus und den einzelnen Geländefeldern innerhalb dieser Länder sind die historisch korrekten Städtenamen zugewiesen, welche Sie wiederum zu Ihren Einzigartigen Historischen Siegen (EHS) führen. Bei den meisten territorialen EHS ("Bringen Sie den Balkan unter Ihre Kontrolle", "Bringen Sie Mesopotamien unter Ihre Kontrolle" etc.) müssen Sie bis zu 3 Städte in der betreffenden Region in Ihren Besitz bringen. Besonders hohe Anforderungen stellt dagegen Rom, denn hier müssen Sie gleich 3 Städte in Iberien, 3 in Frankreich, 3 in Nordafrika, 2 in Deutschland, 1 in England und 3 in Italien einnehmen.[PARAGRAPH:2]In Dawn of Civilization, the Regionen, die für Ihren EHS relevant sind, werden im Tooltip angezeigt, wenn Sie mit dem Cursor auf das entsprechende Feld zeigen.
TEXT.Italian: [H1]Continenti, paesi e Vittorie Storiche uniche[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Rhye ha diviso la mappa mondiale in continenti separati. Una meraviglia costruita in Cina non avrà più effetto su una città in Sud Africa. In questo modo Rhye ha anche ulteriormente suddiviso il mondo in Paesi, assegnando addirittura nomi precisi di città alle singole caselle. Questi nomi saranno la tua guida per le vittorie storiche. Per la maggior parte delle vittorie storiche legate ai territori (controlla i Balcani, controlla la Mesopotamia, ecc.) ti verrà chiesto di controllare 3 città nella zona. Roma è la più difficile, visto che servono 3 città in Spagna, 3 in Francia, 3 nell'Africa settentrionale, 2 in Germania, 1 in Inghilterra e 3 in Italia.
TEXT.Spanish: [H1]Continentes, países y victorias históricas únicas[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Rhye ha dividido el mapamundi en continentes separados. Una maravilla construida en China ya no producirá efectos en Sudáfrica. De la misma manera, Rhye también ha dividido el mundo en países, y ha asignado nombres de ciudades históricas con precisión a las casillas individuales. Esos nombres te servirán de guía para las victorias históricas. En la mayoría de las victorias históricas territoriales (controlar los Balcanes, controlar Mesopotamia, etc.) tendrás que controlar hasta 4 ciudades de la zona. Roma es la más estricta, pues exige 3 ciudades en la península Ibérica, 3 en Francia, 3 en el norte de África, 2 en Alemania, 1 en Inglaterra y 3 en Italia.

TEXT.English: [H1]Diplomatic Institutions[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]The [BOLD]Apostolic Palace[\BOLD] and [BOLD]United Nations[\BOLD] have seen some changes in Dawn of Civilizations. Several rules have been modified and certain resolutions were to increase their impact and make them more interesting to interact with. General changes: [ICON_BULLET]Instead of being directly proportional to population, the number of votes of a civilization are now proportional to the square root of its population. This reduces the influence of large civilizations and makes cooperation with smaller civilizations more important. [ICON_BULLET]Defying resolutions now follows different rules for the two institutions. [ICON_BULLET]When a civilization attempts to win a diplomatic victory, its own votes and the votes of its vassals are disregarded. Instead it needs to win a majority among the remaining votes. This way, the diplomatic victory truly requires diplomacy, and cannot be achieved by military subjugation. [H2]Apostolic Palace[\H2] [ICON_BULLET]Apostolic Palace elections triggered by constructing Saint Peter's Basilica [ICON_BULLET]Only civilizations with Catholic state religions are members of the Apostolic Palace and allowed to vote. [ICON_BULLET]Resolutions that affect all members don't fail only because a member defies it. [ICON_BULLET]Instead, civilizations defying resolutions are not affected by them. The usual penalties (loss of membership, unhappiness, diplomatic penalties) still apply. [ICON_BULLET]Renamed the "Declare War" resolutions to "Crusade". Valid targets are non-members who are at war with a member (defensive crusade) and non-members who control the Catholic holy city or shrine (offensive crusade). [ICON_BULLET]New "Collect Tithe" resolution: all members pay 10% of their treasury of which the Pope receives half. [ICON_BULLET]New "Send Inquisition" resolution: the Pope receives additional espionage against the target civilization. [ICON_BULLET]New "Excommunication" resolution: the target loses membership and receives unhappiness as if they had defied a resolution. [H2]United Nations[\H2] [ICON_BULLET]Security Council: only the four civilizations with the highest military power are allowed to defy resolutions. [ICON_BULLET]New "Decolonize City" resolution: Cities on other continents can be forced to be liberated to independents. [ICON_BULLET]New "Release Civilization" resolution: If a civilization can respawn, another civilization controlling their territory can be forced to release it.

[H1]Historical Starts[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]This is why your game won't start immediately for most Civs. Rhye's mod, above all else, was designed to mirror history. As such, most civs spawn many years into the game, as late as 1867 for Canada. If you want to play as a late spawning civ now, load up one of the quick starts. Don't worry about being behind; you will start with many units and techs to place you on an even footing with the AIs.[PARAGRAPH:2]In addition to all those units and techs, you may even have some cities flip for you. Although, be aware when playing imperialistic civilizations such as Persia, Rome and Arabia. New civs will carve their empires out of your land! If you refuse to let go of the cities, units in the area will join the resistance for several turns. If you decide to resist the wave of nationalism, make sure your army is large enough to handle defectors!
TEXT.French: [H1]Débuts historiques[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]L'absence de la plupart des civilisations au début du jeu a une explication. Le mod de Rhye a été conçu avant tout pour refléter l'histoire. Par conséquent, beaucoup de civilisations apparaissent assez tardivement dans le jeu, la dernière étant l'Amérique en 1733. Si vous voulez jouer tout de suite avec une des civilisations tardives, chargez une des sauvegardes rapides. Pour que vous ne soyez pas défavorisé par rapport à l'IA, vous commencerez avec un grand nombre de technologies et d'unités.[PARAGRAPH:2]En plus de disposer de nombreuses unités et technologies, vous pourrez même prendre le contrôle de certaines villes. Cependant, prenez garde si vous jouez avec des civilisations impérialistes comme la Perse, l'Arabie ou Rome. De nouvelles civilisations se tailleront un empire dans votre territoire ! Si vous refusez de leur céder vos villes, des unités de la zone rejoindront la résistance pendant plusieurs tours. Si vous décidez de résister à la vague de nationalisme, assurez-vous que votre armée est assez grande pour faire face aux transfuges !
TEXT.German: [H1]Historische Starts[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Diese Einstellung verhindert für die meisten Zivilisationen einen sofortigen Spielstart. Das Rhye's-Mod wurde in erster Linie so entworfen, dass es die Geschichte realistisch widerspiegelt. Dementsprechend stoßen die meisten Zivilisationen - wie geschichtlich belegt - erst nach vielen Jahren zum Spiel hinzu, als letzte Nation Amerika im Jahr 1733. Wenn Sie mit einer dieser erst in späteren Jahren hinzukommenden Nationen spielen wollen, sollten Sie eine der Schnellstartoptionen laden. Und machen Sie sich keine Gedanken darüber, dass Sie in diesem Fall vielleicht zu rückständig starten: Sie werden das Spiel mit zahlreichen Einheiten und Technologien beginnen, damit Sie den KIs ebenbürtig sind.[PARAGRAPH:2]Neben diesen Einheiten und Technologien könnten auch gleich zu Beginn einige Städte ihr Interesse bekunden, sich Ihrer Zivilisation anschließen zu wollen. Hier ist allerdings Vorsicht geboten, wenn Sie das Spiel mit einer imperialistischen Zivilisation wie Persien, Rom oder Arabien bestreiten, denn wiederum später neu entstehende Zivilisationen werden ihre Reiche auf Teilen Ihres bisherigen Territoriums aufbauen! Und sollten Sie sich weigern, Ihre Städte, die sich möglicherweise einer solchen neuen Nation anschließen möchte, ziehen zu lassen, werden sich die umliegenden Einheiten einige Runden lang dem Widerstand anschließen. Für den Fall, dass Sie vorhaben, sich der Welle des Nationalismus zu widersetzen, sollten Sie sicherstellen, dass Ihre Armee groß genug ist, um mit Überläufern fertig zu werden!
TEXT.Italian: [H1]Avvii storici[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Ecco perché la partita non comincerà immediatamente, per la maggior parte delle civiltà. Questo mod, per prima cosa, è stato pensato per riprodurre la storia, per cui molte civiltà nasceranno molti anni dopo l'inizio del gioco, fino al 1733 dell'America. Se vuoi giocare subito una delle civiltà che nascono tardi, carica uno degli avvii rapidi. Non preoccuparti di restare indietro: comincerai con abbastanza unità e tecnologie da metterti alla pari con l'IA.[PARAGRAPH:2]Oltre ad avere tutte le unità e tecnologie, potresti addirittura ottenere che qualche città cambi schieramento. Attento però, che quando giochi con civiltà imperialiste come quella persiana, romana o araba, le nuove civiltà creeranno i propri imperi con le tue terre! Se ti rifiuti di lasciar andare le città, le unità della zona si uniranno per diversi turni alla resistenza. Se decidi di resistere all'ondata di nazionalismo assicurati che il tuo esercito sia abbastanza grande da gestire i disertori!
TEXT.Spanish: [H1]Comienzos históricos[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]A continuación se explica por qué la mayoría de las civilizaciones no comenzarán inmediatamente. El mod de Rhye ha sido diseñado para reflejar la historia por encima de todo lo demás. Por ello, la mayoría de las civilizaciones aparecen tarde en la partida, como Estados Unidos, que lo hace en 1733. Si quieres jugar con una de las civilizaciones que aparecen tarde, carga uno de los inicios rápidos. Sin embargo, no te quedarás atrás, pues comenzarás con muchas unidades y tecnologías que equilibrarán tu posición con la de las IA.[PARAGRAPH:2]Además de todas esas unidades y tecnologías, también podrían unírsete algunas ciudades. Ten cuidado al jugar con algunas civilizaciones imperialistas, como Persia, Roma y Arabia, ¡pues surgirán nuevas civilizaciones que querrán labrar su imperio con tus territorios! Si te niegas a hacer concesiones a las ciudades, las unidades de la zona se unirán a la resistencia durante varios turnos. Si decides resistirte al empuje del nacionalismo, ¡no olvides mantener un ejército lo bastante grande como para que las deserciones no sean un problema!

TEXT.English: [H1]Corporations in Dawn of Civilization[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Corporation headquarters and executives have been removed in Dawn of Civilization. Instead, corporations spread on their own to cities that can attract them. To be able to attract a corporation, you need to have the associated technology and control at least one of the consumed resources. The chance increases by acquiring more resources, constructing appropriate buildings or adopting the Free Market civic. The number of cities per corporation is limited, so corporations can also leave one city and move to another that fulfills its requirements better. Certain corporations also compete with each other, reducing the chance of being present in the same city.[PARAGRAPH:2]The Silk Route and Trading Company corporations behave differently from the others. They don't require the Corporation technology to spread to your cities, but are limited to certain historical regions of the map. Also, they expire after a certain date and start to leave your cities.

[H1]Odds and Ends[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2] [ICON_BULLET]Jungles are impassable by most units and cannot be chopped until Biology. [ICON_BULLET]Swamp is a new tile, and it may never be cleared. [ICON_BULLET]A new luxury resource, Cotton, has been added. [ICON_BULLET]Shrines are capped at +20 [ICON_BULLET]Corporations will consume a maximum of 12 resources. [ICON_BULLET]Tech costs increase as you grow [ICON_BULLET]Nukes do much more damage and are now a deadly weapon.

[H1]Plague[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]The most controversial and bemoaned addition to this mod, Plague has made RFC more dynamic than even Stability. There are 5 pre-determined Plague spawns. They occur roughly at 400AD, 1300AD, 1650AD and 1850AD. There is a fifth plague that spawns only in Meso-America when Europeans first make contact. This is meant to simulate the spread of Smallpox. But fear not! There are many ways for you to control the spread and duration of the plague.[PARAGRAPH:2]Plague spreads through foreign contact and proximity to infected cities. You can limit this spread by canceling open borders and limiting your trade connections. The major determining factor in catching plague is your health surplus. Having far more health bonuses than unhealthiness will prevent the plague from spreading to your cities. Even if you don't reach the preventative threshold, high health will lessen the duration and severity of the plague. Granaries, Baths, Wharfs and Pharmacies are all vital to any populous empire. Even with these precautions, once a city catches plague, there is little you can do to prevent the spread to neighboring cities. Discovering Microbiology will stop the plague from spreading regardless of your healthiness.
TEXT.French: [H1]Peste[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Bien que ce soit l'ajout le plus controversé et le plus contesté de ce mod, la peste donne encore plus de dynamisme à RFC que la stabilité. Il y a cinq épidémies de peste prédéfinies. Elles éclatent approximativement vers 400 apr. J.-C., 1300 apr. J.-C., 1650 apr. J.-C. et 1850 apr. J.-C. La cinquième épidémie de peste éclate seulement en Méso-Amérique, quand les Européens la découvrent pour la première fois. Cette dernière épidémie sert à simuler la propagation de la variole. Mais n'ayez crainte ! Vous pouvez contrôler la propagation et la durée de la peste de nombreuses façons.[PARAGRAPH:2]La propagation de la peste est favorisée par les contacts avec l'étranger et la proximité de villes contaminées. Vous pouvez limiter cette propagation en annulant les accords de libre passage, en instaurant le mercantilisme et en évitant de construire des ambassades. Le facteur déterminant dans l'apparition de la peste est le niveau de santé. Si vous avez bien plus de bonus de santé que de malus, vos villes ne seront pas touchées par la peste. Même si vous n'atteignez pas le seuil d'immunisation, une santé élevée réduira la durée et la gravité de la maladie. Les greniers, les aqueducs, les ports et les épiceries sont essentiels pour tout empire peuplé. Si, malgré vos précautions, la peste apparaissait dans l'une de vos villes, vous ne pourrez pas faire grand-chose pour empêcher l'épidémie de gagner les villes voisines. En découvrant la médecine, vous pouvez enrayer la propagation de la peste, quel que soit votre niveau de santé.
TEXT.German: [H1]Pest[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Die kontroverseste und umstrittenste Neuerung in diesem Mod ist, dass die Pest RFC noch dynamischer gestaltet als die Stabilität. Es gibt 5 vorbestimmte Pestausbrüche, die in etwa um 400 n. Chr., 1300 n. Chr., 1650 n. Chr. und 1850 n. Chr. stattfinden. Die fünfte Pestepidemie bricht nur in Mesoamerika aus, und zwar beim ersten Kontakt mit den Europäern - damit soll die Verbreitung der Pocken simuliert werden. Aber keine Sorge: Sie haben viele Möglichkeiten, die Ausbreitung und Dauer der Pest zu kontrollieren.[PARAGRAPH:2]Die Verbreitung der Pest erfolgt durch den Kontakt mit Fremden und die Nähe zu infizierten Städten. Sie können sie aber eindämmen, indem Sie Offene-Grenzen-Abkommen aufheben und Handelsverbindungen begrenzen. Der entscheidende Faktor bei der Bekämpfung der Pest ist jedoch Ihr "Gesundheitsüberschuss": Wenn Sie deutlich mehr Gesundheitsboni vorweisen können als Krankheitsfaktoren, wird dies die Ausbreitung der Pest in Ihren Städten verhindern. Und auch wenn Sie den präventiven Schwellenwert nicht erreichen, wird ein hoher Gesundheitswert die Dauer und Intensität der Pest mindern. Kornspeicher, Bäder, Docks und Apotheken sind für eine bevölkerungsreiche Nation allerdings unerlässlich. Trotz aller Vorsichtsmaßnahmen gibt es, wenn die Pest erst einmal in einer Stadt aufgetreten ist, nur wenig Möglichkeiten, ein Übergreifen auf benachbarte Städte zu unterbinden - lediglich die Entdeckung der "Mikrobiologie" kann die Pest unabhängig von dem aktuellen Gesundheitswert stoppen.
TEXT.Italian: [H1]Peste[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]La più controversa e criticata aggiunta a questo mod è la peste, che lo ha reso dinamico ancor più della stabilità. La peste si verifica in 5 occasioni predeterminate: circa nel 400 d.C., 1300 d.C:, 1650 d.C: e 1850 d.C. La quinta volta accade solo nel centro America, all'arrivo degli europei; l'intento è simulare lo scoppio dell'epidemia di vaiolo. Ma non temere! Hai molti modi per controllare la diffusione e la durata delle epidemie.[PARAGRAPH:2]La peste si diffonde tramite il contatto con gli stranieri e la vicinanza alle città infette. Puoi limitare questo tipo di diffusione annullando il diritto di passaggio, usando il mercantilismo come forma di governo e non costruendo ambasciate. Il fattore più determinante è comunque il surplus di salute. Se i bonus di salute superano la mancanza di salute impedirai alla peste di diffondersi nelle tue città. Anche se non raggiungi il limite di prevenzione, tanta salute farà in modo che la peste duri meno e sia meno grave. Granai, acquedotti, porti e droghieri sono essenziali per la vita di qualsiasi impero popoloso. Anche con queste precauzioni, una volta che una città ha preso la peste puoi fare ben poco per impedire che si diffonda nelle città vicine. Se scopri la medicina impedirai la diffusione della peste a prescindere dalla salute.
TEXT.Spanish: [H1]Peste[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]La novedad más polémica de este mod es la relativa a la peste, ya que ha suscitado aún más comentarios de la comunidad que la relativa a la estabilidad. Hay cinco momentos predeterminados en los que surgirá la peste. Ésta se producirá aproximadamente en torno a los años 400, 1300, 1650 y 1850, todos ellos d. C. Y la quinta peste se produce únicamente en Centroamérica, cuando se traban los primeros contactos con los europeos (esta última simulará la propagación de la viruela). ¡Pero no temas! Existen muchas formas de controlar la propagación y la duración de la peste.[PARAGRAPH:2]La peste se propaga gracias al contacto con extranjeros y a la proximidad con ciudades infectadas. Puedes limitar su propagación si cierras las fronteras, empleas el Mercantilismo y evitas abrir embajadas. El factor más determinante a la hora de controlar la peste es tu excedente de salud. Disponer de más bonificaciones de salud que de insalubridad evitará que la peste se extienda por tus ciudades. Incluso si no alcanzas el umbral preventivo, una salud elevada reducirá la duración y la gravedad de la peste. Los graneros, los acueductos, los puertos y los colmados son vitales para conseguir un imperio bien poblado. Si la peste entra en una ciudad a pesar de todas esas precauciones, poco puede hacerse para evitar que se extienda a las ciudades vecinas. El descubrimiento de la medicina evitará que la peste se extienda, independientemente de tu nivel de salud.

TEXT.English: [H1]Rebirths and Resurrections in Dawn of Civilization[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]There are different mechanics for collapsed civilizations to return into the game. Resurrection refers to the rules already present in vanilla RFC that allow a civilization to return if its core is controlled by independents or an unstable civilization. This effect is limited to certain periods in Dawn of Civilization, to prevent ahistorical respawns of ancient and classical civs. Also, it's not necessary to discover Nationalism to enable this mechanism, although it increases the probability of resurrections. This means that you will see resurrections occur earlier in the game. Outside of periodic checks, these resurrections can also occur when an unstable civilization collapses - if their territory includes the core of a civilization that can return, these cities will become part of this civilization instead of being independent.[PARAGRAPH:2]Dawn of Civilization also adds another mechanic that is referred to as rebirths. These are scripted and return a specific dead civ at specific dates, if certain conditions are met. Also, the faction now represents a completely new civilization with UU, UB, UP and UHV. Players can take control of these civilizations and complete their victory goals by switching to them, even if they have switched once already. Currently, this mechanic covers the rebirths of Persia as Iran, Maya as Colombia and Aztecs as Mexico.

[H1]Welcome to Rhye's and Fall of Civilization[\H1][PARAGRAPH:0]v1.187[PARAGRAPH:2]Rhye's and Fall of Civilization is a mod based on a map of the world, that attempts to make your single-player game a realistic simulator of history on Earth. It is the sequel to "Rhye's of Civilization", one of the most popular modpacks for Civilization III. [PARAGRAPH:2]The mod revolves around the historic rise and fall of civilizations: they won't start all at the same time, but at appropriate dates. The human player can choose a late start (waiting for the game to play by itself) or take the control of one of the early civs and switch to another one later on. Civilizations will fall by many factors, including civil wars caused by inner instability, and scripted barbarian attacks.[PARAGRAPH:2]Each civilization is heavily differentiated from the others, thanks to the UPs (Unique Powers), the UHVs (Unique Historical Victory conditions), and a unique AI that will found cities in their historical place, with their historical name.[PARAGRAPH:2]Other additions include plague outbreaks, embassies, world congresses where cities are traded, dynamic spread of the resources, and new flag and terrain graphics.[PARAGRAPH:2]More detailed info is provided in the readme. For any other question you can visit the official site (http://rhye.civfanatics.net), the development forum (http://forums.civfanatics.com/forumdisplay.php?f=204) or the wiki (http://rhye.civfanatics.net/wiki/), which contains useful strategy guides.
TEXT.French: [H1]Bienvenue à "Rhye's and Fall of Civilization"[\H1][PARAGRAPH:0]v1.187[PARAGRAPH:2]"Rhye's and Fall of Civilization" est un mod basé sur une carte du monde, qui tente de rendre votre partie aussi proche de la réalité historique que possible. Il s'agit de la suite de "Rhye's of Civilization", l'un des mods les plus populaires de Civilization III . [PARAGRAPH:2]Ce mod est basé sur l'essor et la chute des civilisations tels que ces événements se sont réellement déroulés. Toutes ces civilisations ne démarreront pas en même temps, mais aux dates appropriées. Le joueur peut choisir de commencer plus tard (la partie démarre alors sans lui) ou de prendre le contrôle de l'une des premières civilisations pour en changer plus tard. Les civilisations chuteront en raison de nombreux facteurs, dont les guerres civiles causées par l'instabilité du pays et les attaques barbares scénarisées.[PARAGRAPH:2]Chaque civilisation est extrêmement différente des autres, grâce aux PU (Pouvoirs uniques), aux VHU (conditions de Victoires Historiques Uniques), et à une IA unique qui fondera les villes dans leur site historique et leur donnera le nom qu’elles ont réellement porté.[PARAGRAPH:2]Parmi les nouveautés, citons les épidémies de peste, les ambassades, les congrès mondiaux où sont échangées les villes, la propagation dynamique des ressources et de nouveaux graphismes pour les drapeaux et les terrains.[PARAGRAPH:2]Vous trouverez de plus amples informations dans la section Lisez-moi. Vous pouvez également consulter le site officiel (http://rhye.civfanatics.net), le forum de développement (http://forums.civfanatics.com/forumdisplay.php?f=204) ou l'encyclopédie (http://rhye.civfanatics.net/wiki/), laquelle contient de nombreux conseils stratégiques.
TEXT.German: [H1]Willkommen zu Rhye's and Fall of Civilization[\H1][PARAGRAPH:0]v1.187[PARAGRAPH:2]Rhye's and Fall of Civilization ist ein Mod, das auf einer Weltkarte basiert, um das Einzelspielerspiel zu einer realistischen Simulation der Geschichte der Erde zu machen. Es ist die Fortsetzung von "Rhye's of Civilization", eines der bekanntesten Mod-Pakete für Civilization III. [PARAGRAPH:2]Das Mod handelt vom historischen Aufstieg und Fall der Zivilisationen: Sie beginnen nicht alle zur selben Zeit, sondern zum passenden Zeitpunkt. Der Spieler kann einen späten Start wählen (und warten, bis das Spiel so weit vorangeschritten ist) oder die Kontrolle über eine der frühen Zivilisationen übernehmen und später dann zu einer anderen wechseln. Der Fall von Zivilisationen wird von vielen Faktoren beeinflusst, wie etwa Bürgerkriege, die durch innere Instabilität ausgelöst werden, und programmierte Angriffe von Barbaren.[PARAGRAPH:2]Jede Zivilisation unterscheidet sich von den anderen durch die EMs (Einzigartigen Mächte), die EHS (Einzigartigen historischen Siegbedingungen) und eine einzigartige KI, die Städte an historischen Orten und mit ihrem historischen Namen errichten wird.[PARAGRAPH:2]Andere Ergänzungen beinhalten den Ausbruch der Pest, Botschaften, Weltkongresse, bei denen ganze Städte verkauft werden, dynamische Verteilung der Ressourcen und neue Gelände- und Flaggengrafiken.[PARAGRAPH:2]Genauere Informationen finden Sie im ReadMe. Für weitergehende Fragen, sehen Sie bitte auf der offiziellen Website (http://rhye.civfanatics.net), dem Entwicklerforum (http://forums.civfanatics.com/forumdisplay.php?f=204) oder der Wikipedia (http://rhye.civfanatics.net/wiki/) nach. Hier finden Sie hilfreiche Strategietipps.
TEXT.Italian: [H1]Benvenuto a Rhye's and Fall[\H1][PARAGRAPH:0]v1.187[PARAGRAPH:2]Rhye's and Fall è un mod basato sulla mappa del mondo, che cerca di trasformare una partita per giocatore singolo in un simulatore realistico di storia della Terra. È il seguito di "Rhye's of Civilization", uno dei mod più popolari per Civilization III. [PARAGRAPH:2]Il mod ruota attorno all'ascesa e al declino delle civiltà storiche: non avranno tutte inizio nel medesimo istante, ma nella propria epoca. Il giocatore può scegliere un avvio in ritardo (lasciando che la partita evolva per conto proprio) o prendere subito il controllo di una delle prime civiltà e passare a un'altra in un secondo momento. Le civiltà cadranno per diversi motivi, tra cui guerre civili scatenate da instabilità interna, e attacchi dei barbari programmati.[PARAGRAPH:2]Ogni civiltà è estremamente diversa dalle altre, grazie ai poteri unici, le condizioni di vittoria uniche e una intelligenza artificiale che fonderà le città nella loro corretta ubicazione storica, con il loro vero nome.[PARAGRAPH:2]Tra le altre aggiunte ci sono le epidemie di peste, le ambasciate, i congressi mondiali nei quali scambiare le città, la diffusione dinamica delle risorse, e una nuova grafica per bandiere e terreno.[PARAGRAPH:2]Il file readme contiene ulteriori informazioni. Per ogni altro dubbio potete visitare il sito ufficiale (http://rhye.civfanatics.net), il forum degli sviluppatori (http://forums.civfanatics.com/forumdisplay.php?f=204) o la voce wiki (http://rhye.civfanatics.net/wiki/), che contiene utili consigli strategici.
TEXT.Spanish: [H1]Bienvenido a "Rhye's and Fall of Civilization"[\H1][PARAGRAPH:0]v1.187[PARAGRAPH:2]"Rhye's and Fall of Civilization" es un mod basado en un mapa del mundo que intenta hacer que la partida para un jugador sea una simulación realista de la historia de la Tierra. Es la secuela de "Rhye's of Civilization", uno de los mods más populares de Civilization III. [PARAGRAPH:2]El mod gira en torno al auge y caída históricos de las civilizaciones: no empezarán todas al mismo tiempo, sino en las fechas precisas. El jugador puede optar por un inicio tardío (si se espera a que el programa juegue por sí mismo) o tomar el control de una de las civilizaciones y cambiar posteriormente a otra. Las civilizaciones pueden caer por muchos factores, incluyendo las guerras civiles causadas por la inestabilidad interna y los ataques bárbaros programados en el script.[PARAGRAPH:2]Cada civilización se diferencia acusadamente de las demás gracias a los PU (poderes únicos), las condiciones UVH (condiciones únicas para la victoria histórica) y una IA propia que ubicará las ciudades en su emplazamiento histórico y les dará su nombre real.[PARAGRAPH:2]Otros añadidos incluyen apariciones de plagas, embajadas, congresos mundiales donde se intercambian ciudades, una propagación dinámica de los recursos y nuevos gráficos para las marcas y terrenos.[PARAGRAPH:2]En el documento "Readme (Léame)" se proporciona información más detallada. Para cualquier otra cuestión, visita la página oficial (http://rhye.civfanatics.net), el foro de desarrollo (http://forums.civfanatics.com/forumdisplay.php?f=204) o la wikiguía (http://rhye.civfanatics.net/wiki/), que contiene consejos útiles sobre la estrategia.

TEXT.English: [H1]Welcome to Dawn of Civilization[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Dawn of Civilization (DoC) is a ModMod made by Leoreth based on Rhye's and Fall of Civilization. It adds many features, which can be found in Section 2 of the Concepts pages.

[H1]Slavery[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Dawn of Civilization aims to represent the transatlantic slave trade as part of the Columbian Exchange. To this purpose, a slave unit has been added to the game. [NEWLINE][BOLD]Capturing slave units[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Slave units cannot be trained. Instead it is possible to capture them in combat. This is enabled by two civics: Slavery (Society) and Colonialism (Territory). Every time when defeating a Native unit while running one of these civics, there is a chance of receiving a slave unit. [NEWLINE][BOLD]Trading slave units[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]The other option to acquire slaves is by trade. This is only enabled for civilizations that control at least one colony. If any of the civilizations participating in a trade has colonies, slave units will appear on the table just like resources, techs etc. [NEWLINE][BOLD]Using slave units[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]It is only possible to use slaves in the Americas and Sub-Saharan Africa. In addition, certain civics (Egalitarianism, Nationhood, and Multilateralism) prevent the use of slaves. The possible actions for slaves are: [NEWLINE][BOLD]Build a slave plantation:[\BOLD] the slave can build a slave plantation on all tiles that have a resource which requires a plantation, yielding +1 [ICON_PRODUCTION] and +2 [ICON_COMMERCE] compared to a normal plantation. The slave is used in the process, similar to a work boat. [NEWLINE][BOLD]Join city as a slave specialist:[\BOLD] the slave can permanently join the city as a slave specialist, yielding 2 [ICON_PRODUCTION] and creating 1 [ICON_UNHAPPY]. The number of slaves per city is limited to half of its population. [NEWLINE][BOLD]Freeing the slaves[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Slave effects (plantations and specialists) only remain active as long as you can use slaves (see above). When you abandon the civics required for slavery, Slave Plantations will revert to ordinary Plantations and Slave specialists will be removed. Likewise, when territory with a Slave Plantation is acquired by a civilization that cannot use slaves, it will revert to a Plantation. Slaves present in cities will always be freed on conquest. If the conqueror can also use slaves, they will receive an equivalent number of Slave units in return. [NEWLINE][BOLD]The Aztecs[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]The Aztec unique power enables them to acquire slave units by winning battles; regardless of the losing unit there is a chance of acquiring a slave unit. Aztec slaves also have the additional abilities of acting as workers and can be sacrificed in their cities, as a way to temporarily increase happiness there.

[H1]Stability Influence Factors[\H1] [NEWLINE][BOLD]EXPANSION[\BOLD] [NEWLINE][BOLD]Overextension[\BOLD] Overextension is the main factor of expansion stability. It depends on two scores: [ICON_BULLET]core population score [ICON_BULLET]periphery population score [NEWLINE]Without taking modifiers into account, they are just the population in your core and the population outside of your core, respectively. As long as your periphery population score is below your core population score, everything is fine. Once the periphery score exceeds 100% of the core population score, you will receive an expansion stability penalty according to a formula which I will explain later. The scores are affected by a number of modifiers and therefore aren't only based on city population. [NEWLINE]The [BOLD]core population score[\BOLD] is multiplied by your current era plus one. Since the modifier is era-based, your ability to support a large periphery grows during the game. [NEWLINE]The [BOLD]periphery population score[\BOLD] for every city is based on many different factors. Since a lower periphery score is better for stability, negative modifiers are desired. +2 if the city is not on historical territory (so it makes sense to mainly control historical tiles) +1 if you are not the original owner of this city (unless you are running Totalitarianism, or the city is under your control for more than 25 turns) +1 if you have less than 50% culture in this city +1 if you have less than 20% culture in this city (those two penalties are cumulative, for a total of +2 if you are below 20%. Culture counts double within their civilization's own cores. Persia is immune to culture-based penalties due to their UP) +1 if it is a historical overseas city and you are running Totalitarianism -1 if the city has a Courthouse -1 if the city has a Jail -1 if it is a historical overseas city and you are running Colonialism -1 if it is an overseas city and you are Portugal (their UP)
[NEWLINE]In addition to city population, each Village and Town in your core counts as one core population. [NEWLINE]The expansion penalty can be at most -25, and grows faster right after the periphery score exceeds the core score than later on. This allows a diminishing yet growing effect of expansion stability that allows playing Domination games without making expansion stability irrelevant in more historical games. [NEWLINE]Between stability checks, the overextension penalty can only increase by at most 5 negative points. For instance, if you had a penalty of 0 in the last check and the calculation results in -10, you will still only get a penalty of -5 until the next check. [NEWLINE]Adopting Isolationism and keeping your periphery population at 10 or lower will give you +10 stability. [NEWLINE][BOLD]Recent Expansion[\BOLD] Founding and conquering cities in your historical area provides positive stability. The effect lasts for 20 turns from when the city has been acquired. The stability from recently conquered cities is higher when running Conquest and due to the Persian UP. [NEWLINE][BOLD]Razing[\BOLD] You get a -10 stability penalty for every city you have razed. This penalty decays by 2 points every 5 turns. This penalty is global, that means if you accrue -20 raze stability from razing two cities, it still decays by 2 points every 5 turns, instead of by 4. The exception to this rule are smaller cities. If the city has never had a population of more than 5, the penalty is -2 * [highest population the city has had] instead. This exception does not apply to another civilizations capital, which always gives a -10 penalty when razed. Barbarian-owned cities will not count for this penalty, while cities owned by minor civilizations are worth only half of the usual penalty points. [NEWLINE][BOLD]ECONOMY[\BOLD] [NEWLINE][BOLD]Economic Growth[\BOLD] The economic growth score is updated every third turn, in which the total amount of commerce produced is compared to the amount from three turns earlier. Has it grown by more than 5%, the score increases, has it shrunk by more than 5%, it decreases. Otherwise the score slowly moves towards 0 again. At every stability check the score is directly applied to the economy stability. [NEWLINE][BOLD]DOMESTIC[\BOLD] [NEWLINE][BOLD]Happiness[\BOLD] Happiness stability works similar to economic growth stability in that it is accumulating every third turn depending on the situation of your civilization. To that end, the happy and unhappy cities in a civilization are counted based on the following criteria: [NEWLINE][BOLD]Happy city:[\BOLD] currently celebrates the "We Love the King" day OR its happiness exceeds its unhappiness by at least a quarter of your empire's average city size and it has at least the average city size of your empire [BOLD]Unhappy city:[\BOLD] the city has more unhappiness than happiness OR the extra unhappiness (from all factors except population) exceeds a fifth of the city's population [NEWLINE]Note that it is possible for a city to not fulfill either of these criteria, in which case it doesn't count at all for the purposes of happiness stability. A city can also both fulfill the criteria for being happy and unhappy, in which case it counts as happy. Your happiness stability grows every third turn if you have more happy than unhappy cities, and declines if you have more unhappy than happy cities. This factor cannot exceed -5 or 5, respectively. If the amount of happy and unhappy cities is exactly the same, the value slowly approaches 0 again. [NEWLINE][BOLD]Religion[\BOLD] For religions, two or three percentages are calculated: [ICON_BULLET]the percentage of cities that have your state religion (believer ratio) [ICON_BULLET]the percentage of cities that have at least one non-state religion (heathen ratio) [ICON_BULLET]if you are running Theocracy, the percentage of cities that have ONLY your state religion [NEWLINE]Some non-state religions are ignored for the purposes of the second and third ratios ("tolerance"). [ICON_BULLET]civs with either Tolerance or Secularism tolerate all non-state religions [ICON_BULLET]Hinduism and Buddhism tolerate each other [ICON_BULLET]Confucianism and Taoism tolerate each other [NEWLINE][BOLD]Heathen ratio:[\BOLD] You incur neither penalties nor bonuses if your ratio is 30%. Otherwise, you receive -1 stability for every 10% over 30% and +1 stability for every 10% below 30%. [BOLD]Believer ratio:[\BOLD] You incur neither penalties nor bonuses if your ratio is 75%. Otherwise, you receive -1 stability for every 5% below 75% (up to a maximum of -10) and +1 stability for every 5% over 75%. [BOLD]Theocracy bonus:[\BOLD] if you are running Theocracy, you also receive +1 stability for every 20% of your cities that only have your state religion. [NEWLINE]Note that while the other factors require you to have a state religion, the religion stability from the heathen ratio also applies when you don't have a state religion. [NEWLINE][BOLD]Civics[\BOLD] Civics stability comes either from running a certain combination of civics or from running specific civics in a certain era or after discovering a certain technology.
Totalitarianism + State Party: +5 Totalitarianism + Despotism: +3 Totalitarianism + Revolutionism: +3 Totalitarianism + Central Planning: +3 Totalitarianism + Secularism: +2 Totalitarianism + any religious civic except Secularism: -5 Totalitarianism + Constitution: -5 Totalitarianism + Democracy: -3
Central Planning + Egalitarianism: +2 Central Planning + State Party: +2 Central Planning + Centralism: +2
Egalitarianism + Democracy: +2 Egalitarianism + Constitution: +2 Egalitarianism + any religious civic except Tolerance and Secularism: -3
Individualism + Republic or Democracy: +2 Individualism + Free Enterprise: +3 Individualism + Central Planning: -5 Individualism + Regulated Trade or Public Welfare: -2 Individualism + Tolerance: +2
Theocracy + Individualism or Egalitarianism: -3
Deification + Republic or Democracy: -3 Deification + Redistribution before the Medieval era: +2 Deification + Slavery before the Medieval era: +2
Vassalage + Individualism or Egalitarianism: -5 Vassalage + Free Enterprise or Central Planning or Public Welfare: -3 Vassalage + Tributaries: +5 Vassalage + Monarchy in the Medieval era: +2 Vassalage + Manorialism in the Medieval era: +3
Republic + Citizenship: +2 Republic + Vassalage: -3 Republic + Merchant Trade: +2
Centralism + Democracy: -5 Centralism + Regulated Trade: +3 Centralism + Clergy: +2 Centralism + Monarchy in the Renaissance: +2
Despotism + Slavery: +2 Despotism + Nationhood: +3
Caste System + Citizenship: -4 Caste System + Clergy: +2 Caste System + Secularism: -3
Multilateralism + Despotism: -3 Multilateralism + Totalitarianism: -3 Multilateralism + Egalitarianism: +2 Multilateralism + Theocracy: -3
Monarchy + Clergy or Monasticism: +2
Elective + Centralism: -5
Constitution + Democracy: +2
Revolutionism + any religious civic except Tolerance and Secularism: -3
Regulated Trade + Manorialism: +2 Regulated Trade + Meritocracy: +3
Isolationism + Merchant Trade or Free Enterprise: -4 Isolationism + Regulated Trade or Central Planning: +3
Vassalage in the Middle Ages: +2 Vassalage in the Industrial Era or later: -5
Deification in the Classical Era or earlier: +2 Deification after the Classical Era: -2 per era after the Classical Era
Republic in the Classical Era or earlier: +2 Republic in the Industrial Era or later: -5
Isolationism after the Renaissance: -3 per era after the Renaissance
Not running any civic out of Republic, Democracy, Revolutionism or Constitution after the discovery of Representation: -5
Slavery or Manorialism or Caste System after the discovery of Civil Rights: -5
Reciprocity or Redistribution or Merchant Trade after the discovery of Economics: -5

Animism or Deification after the discovery of Theology: -5
Caste System with Hindu state religion: +3
Meritocracy with Confucian state religion: +3
Slavery with Christian or Zoroastrian state religion: -3
Slavery with Muslim state religion: +2
Monasticism with Buddhist state religion: +2 [NEWLINE][BOLD]FOREIGN[\BOLD] [NEWLINE]Several factors contribute to your foreign stability rating: [NEWLINE][BOLD]Vassal stability[\BOLD] Vassals receive +4 stability for every stability level their master exceeds them by
Masters receive:
For every collapsing vassal: -3 For every unstable vassal: -1 For every solid vassal: +2
For every vassal when running Tributaries: +2
[BOLD]Relations stability[\BOLD] If civilisations we know have overall more favourable than unfavourable impressions of us (different relationship factors in the diplomacy tooltip), we receive positive stability, otherwise negative stability. The impact of the effect increases if the relationship factors are at three or more.
For every player that is more powerful and sees you as their worst enemy: -3
With Isolationism, relations stability can never be negative, and positive relations stability is halved.

For every civilisation with a higher score we have a defensive pact with: +3

For every neighbor you are at war with while running Nationhood: +2 For every civilization you are at war with while running Multilateralism: -2 For every civilization with different state religion you are at war with while running Theocracy: +3 For every civilization with the same state religion you are at war with while running Theocracy: -2 [NEWLINE][BOLD]MILITARY[\BOLD] [NEWLINE]All military scores are calculated for each war your civilization is in. [NEWLINE][BOLD]Conquest Stability[\BOLD] This factor depends on the number of cities you have conquered from this civ compared to those you have lost to it. Cities are worth more if the owner has less of them, i.e. losing a city has a larger impact if you don't have a lot of them in the first place. [NEWLINE][BOLD]Battle Stability[\BOLD] Similar to conquest stability, the battles you have won are compared to the battles you have lost. In either case, a battle is "worth" as much as the defeated unit's power rating. How much battle stability you get or lose depends on your overall military strength - the stronger you are, the less of an impact a singular battle has in either way. Battle stability decays while a war lasts. [NEWLINE][BOLD]War Weariness Stability[\BOLD] Your war weariness is compared to your enemy's. If it is larger, you receive a penalty proportional to the difference. This penalty also decays while the war lasts. [NEWLINE][BOLD]Barbarian Losses Stability[\BOLD] You receive a -1 stability penalty for every battle you lose against a barbarian unit. This penalty also decays over time.

[H1]Stability[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]The stability system from Rhye's and Fall has been replaced in Dawn of Civilization, which features a completely redesigned stability mechanic. The main principle of the new system are that there is no permanent stability score. Instead, every civilization has a stability level: Collapsing, Unstable, Shaky, Stable, or Solid. [PARAGRAPH:2]During the game, a number of events (see below) can trigger a stability check. During the check, a score is calculated that reflects the current stability of your empire on a variety of factors in the areas of expansion, economic, domestic, foreign and military. If the score is consistent with your stability level, it remains unchanged. But with exceedingly high or low scores, the stability can either drop or increase a level. However, stability only becomes threatening once it has been reduced all the way to Collapsing, and stability can only decrease or increase by one level by check. This means that higher stability levels provide a buffer against collapse. But even after falling all the way down to Collapsing, your civilisation is not doomed yet. If the next stability check results in the same or a higher stability score, even if it does not improve your stability level to Unstable, your civilisation will remain intact. Otherwise however, it will descend into total collapse and you lose the game. [H2]Stability Levels[\H2]Stability levels represent the overall stability of your empire. Stability levels are persistent and should not be confused with the stability score which is calculated on stability checks according to the rules described below, and then discarded. There are five stability levels from best to worst: [ICON_BULLET]Solid [ICON_BULLET]Stable [ICON_BULLET]Shaky [ICON_BULLET]Unstable [ICON_BULLET]Collapsing Your stability level can change during a stability check. As long it is higher than Collapsing, your empire is safe. High stability levels provide more protection from collapse, since every check can reduce your stability by at most one level. [H2]Stability Checks[\H2]A stability check is when the game determines the current stability score of your civilisation. The following events can trigger a stability check: [ICON_BULLET]losing a city [ICON_BULLET]razing a city (human only) [ICON_BULLET]discovering a technology [ICON_BULLET]becoming a vassal [ICON_BULLET]acquiring a vassal (+) [ICON_BULLET]starting a war [ICON_BULLET]making peace (+) [ICON_BULLET]changing civics or state religion [ICON_BULLET]moving your capital [ICON_BULLET]building a wonder (+) [ICON_BULLET]starting a golden age (+) [ICON_BULLET]receiving a great person (+) [NEWLINE]Events marked with a (+) are positive stability checks. These checks can never reduce your stability level, no matter how bad your stability score is. [NEWLINE]During a check, your stability score is calculated according to the rules described under Stability Influence Factors. This score is compared to the stability threshold. Based on this comparison, the stability check can have three possible outcomes: [NEWLINE][BOLD]Positive:[\BOLD] The stability score exceeds the threshold by more than 10 points [BOLD]Neutral:[\BOLD] The stability score is equal to or greater than the threshold (but by not more than 10 points) [BOLD]Negative:[\BOLD] The stability score is less than the threshold [NEWLINE]The threshold itself depends on your situation. In particular, it depends on the current stability level: [ICON_BULLET]on solid: +20 [ICON_BULLET]on unstable: +10 [ICON_BULLET]on shaky: 0 [ICON_BULLET]on unstable: -10 [ICON_BULLET]on collapsing: -20 [NEWLINE]Due to the different thresholds, it becomes progressively harder to drop to a lower level, and easier to increase your level again. This means that unless something about your civilisation changes to affect your stability score, your stability level will ultimately settle on the level that reflects it. [NEWLINE]The threshold is lower during a Golden Age. This means that Golden Ages can save you from situations that would otherwise lead to collapse, and are the perfect time to increase stability levels again. [NEWLINE]The consequences of the outcome of a stability check are as follows: [BOLD]Positive:[\BOLD] The stability level increases by one. [BOLD]Neutral:[\BOLD] The stability level remains unchanged. [BOLD]Negative:[\BOLD] The stability level decreases by one. If the stability level already was on Collapsing, and the stability score is lower than at the last check, a complete collapse occurs.

[H1]Tile Stability Display[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]In Dawn of Civilization, the stability effect of a specific tile is displayed in the tooltip when you hover over it on the map. The stability categories of tiles are Core (cyan), Historical (light green), Contested (yellow), Foreign (orange) and Foreign Core (red).
