Postal stations were used not only for the transmission and delivery of official mail, but were also available for traveling officials, military men, and foreign dignitaries. These stations aided and facilitated the transport of foreign and domestic tribute, and trade in general. By the end of Kublai Khan's rule there were more than 1400 postal stations in China alone, which in turn had at their disposal about 50000 horses, 1400 oxen, 6700 mules, 400 carts, 6000 boats, over 200 dogs and 1150 sheep.[PARAGRAPH:2]The stations were 15 to 40 miles apart and had reliable attendants working for the mail service. Foreign observers, such as Marco Polo have attested to the efficiency of this early postal system.[PARAGRAPH:2]Another important postal service was created in the Islamic world by the caliph Mu'awiyya; the service was called barid, by the name of the towers built to protect the roads by which couriers travelled.[PARAGRAPH:2]Well before the Middle Ages and during them, homing pigeons were used for pigeon post, taking advantage of a singular quality of this bird, which when taken far from its nest is able to find his way home due to a particularly developed sense of orientation. Messages were then tied around the legs of the pigeon, which was freed and could reach his original nest.[PARAGRAPH:2]Mail has been transported by quite a few other methods throughout history, including dogsled, balloon, rocket, mule, pneumatic tubes and even submarine.[PARAGRAPH:2]Many religious orders had a private mail service, notably Cistercians ' one connected more than 6,000 abbeys, monasteries and churches. The best organization however was created by the Knights Templar. The newly instituted universities too had their private services, starting from Bologna (1158).[PARAGRAPH:2]Popular illiteracy was accommodated through the service of scribes. Illiterates who needed to communicate dictated their messages to a scribe, another profession now quite generally disappeared.[PARAGRAPH:2]In 1505, Holy Roman Emperor Maximilian I established a postal system in the Empire, appointing Franz von Thurn und Taxis to run it. The Thurn and Taxis family, then known as Tassis, had operated postal services between Italian city states from 1290 onwards. Following the abolition of the Empire in 1806 the Thurn and Taxis postal system continued as a private organisation, continuing to exist into the postage stamp era before finally being absorbed into the postal system of the new German Empire after 1871.[PARAGRAPH:2]In the United Kingdom, prior to 1840 the postal system was expensive, confusing and seen as corrupt. Letters were paid for by the recipient rather than the sender, and were charged according to the distance the letter had travelled and the number of sheets of paper it contained. If there is one man who can be said to have changed the face of the postal service forever it is Sir Rowland Hill, with his reforms of the postal system based on the concept of penny postage, and his solution of pre payment. In his proposal Hill also called for official pre-printed envelopes and adhesive postage stamps as alternative ways of getting the sender to pay for the postage, at a time when prepayment was optional, which led to the invention of the postage stamp, the Penny Black.[PARAGRAPH:2]It was around this time nationalization and centralization of most postal systems took place. Today, the study of mail systems is known as postal history.[PARAGRAPH:2]The postal system was important in the development of modern transportation. Railroads carried railway post offices. During the 20th century, air mail became the transport of choice for inter-continental mail. Postmen started to utilize mail trucks. The handling of mail became increasingly automated.[PARAGRAPH:2]The Internet came to change the conditions for physical mail. E-mail (and in recent years social networking sites) became a fierce competitor, but online auctions and Internet shopping opened new business opportunities as people often get items bought online through the mail.

[TAB]A sewer is an artificial conduit (or pipe) or system of conduits used to carry and remove sewage (human liquid waste) and to provide drainage. In the 21st century developed world, sewers are usually pipelines that begin with connecting pipes from buildings to one or more levels of larger underground horizontal mains, which terminate at sewage treatment facilities. Vertical pipes, called manholes, connect the mains to the surface. Sewers are generally gravity powered, though pumps may be used if necessary. [PARAGRAPH:2]The earliest covered sewers uncovered by archaeologists are in the regularly planned cities of the Indus Valley Civilization. In ancient Rome, the Cloaca Maxima, considered a marvel of engineering, disgorged into the Tiber. In medieval European cities, small natural waterways used for carrying off wastewater were eventually covered over and functioned as sewers. London's River Fleet is such a system. Open drains along the center of some streets were known as 'kennels' (= canals, channels).

[TAB]A chiefdom is a form of hierarchical political organization in non-industrial societies usually based on kinship, and in which formal leadership is monopolized by the legitimate senior members of select families or 'houses'. These elites form a political-ideological aristocracy relative to the general group.

[TAB]Unlike traditional monarchies, where rule is hereditary and passed down the family line, under an elective system rulers are chosen by election. Elective systems differ from democracies in that the monarch is generally chosen for life and the right to vote is limited to a small groups of magnates or special members of the aristocracy.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][TAB]Elective systems were prominent in medieval central Europe. In the Holy Roman Empire, the elective system was codified over the centuries to a group of Prince Electors choosing the next Emperor. The Polish king was also elected, first by a small group of nobles, later by the entire noble class. Other European examples include early Scandinavian kings and the Doge of Venice. Outside of Europe, the Mansa of the Mali Empire and the Tlatoani of the Aztec Triple Alliance were selected and confirmed by a privileged council. The selection of the Mongol Great Khan could also be considered an elective monarchy.

[TAB]A one-party state is a type of state in which one political party has the right to form the government, usually based on the existing constitution. All other parties are either outlawed or allowed to take only a limited and controlled participation in elections. One-party states explain themselves through various methods. Most often, proponents of a one-party state argue that the existence of separate parties runs counter to national unity. Others argue that the one party is the vanguard of the people, and therefore its right to rule cannot be legitimately questioned. The Soviet government argued that multiple parties represented the class struggle, which was absent in Soviet society, and so the Soviet Union only had one party: The Communist Party.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][TAB]Most one-party states have been ruled either by parties following the ideology of Marxism–Leninism and international solidarity (such as the Soviet Union for most of its existence), or by parties following some type of nationalist or fascist ideology (such as Italy under Benito Mussolini), or by parties that came to power in the wake of independence from colonial rule. One-party systems often arise from decolonization because one party has had an overwhelmingly dominant role in liberation or in independence struggles.

[TAB]Citizenship describes the legal codification of the relationship between a state and its people. Instead of being just being a subject at the whim of the power of their ruler, the status of citizen comes with certain rights and obligations towards the state. The prime example of citizenship was the Roman Republic. Initially, only inhabitants of Rome could be citizens, which came with access to the Roman legal system, protection from enslavement, and political participation. Over the course of Roman history citizenship was gradually expanded to other populations under Roman rule, which furthered their integration into Roman society.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][TAB]The concept of citizenship continued during the Roman Empire and entered the Western legal tradition. During the Middle Ages, citizenship was replaced by serfdom as the dominant form of social relationship, however the practice continued in independent cities. Modern European states, and later almost all states in the world, conferred citizenship to all its peoples for essentially the same reason the Roman Republic did.

[TAB]Meritocracy is a political philosophy holding that power should be vested in individuals almost exclusively based on ability and talent. Advancement in such a system is based on performance measured through examination and/or demonstrated achievement in the field where it is implemented. According to scholarly consensus, the earliest example of an administrative meritocracy, based on civil service examinations, dates back to Ancient China.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][TAB]The concept originates, at least by the sixth century BC, when it was advocated by the Chinese philosopher Confucius, who "invented the notion that those who govern should do so because of merit, not of inherited status. This sets in motion the creation of the imperial examinations and bureaucracies open only to those who passed tests."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][TAB]As the Qin and Han dynasties developed a meritocratic system in order to maintain power over a large, sprawling empire, it became necessary for the government to maintain a complex network of officials. Prospective officials could come from a rural background and government positions were not restricted to the nobility. Rank was determined by merit, through the civil service examinations, and education became the key for social mobility. After the fall of the Han Dynasty, the nine-rank system was established during the Three Kingdoms period.

[TAB]Centralism describes a form of political organisation where all administrative decisions are made or controlled by the central government situated in the capital. Centralism stands in contrast to more decentralised forms of government such as feudalism or federalism. Ancient China has long had a tradition of central government, where all decisions were carried out by a central bureaucracy loyal to the Emperor.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][TAB]In Europe, feudalism meant that the monarch only had limited power over his domains, since it had to be carried out through noble vassals. In the early modern period, European monarchs sought to increase their power by centralising decisions to the royal court. Archetypal for this development was France under Louis XIV, where the nobility was forced to attend the court at Versailles, so the monarch was able to exert control over them. In consequence, the bureaucracy was expanded to implement royal policy across the country. Other European states quickly emulated the success of this French model.

[TAB]A revolution is a process through which the population overthrows an existing government and establishes a new political order. There are two types of revolution, those that only replace the old elite, and those that fundamentally alter the form of government, its institutions, and social and material relations. In the latter case, a new Revolutionary government is established.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][TAB]Revolutionary governments usually preside over a period of tumultuous change as the old institutions are being abolished and their replacements are being established. At the same time, they are also accompanied by great mobilization and public fervor coming from the parts of the population that have been empowered by the revolution. Revolutionary governments will often attempt to spread their revolutionary ideals to neighboring states both out of conviction and to unite their population against a foreign foe.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][TAB]The French Revolution transformed the absolute monarchy of Ancien Regime France into a Revolutionary Republic, which led to a series of wars against the monarchies of Europe as they tried to contain the revolution. France was generally very successful in these conflicts due to mass mobilization and a motivated citizenry. The republic came to an end with the ascent of Napoleon, but France still kept many revolutionary ideals, which manifested in subsequent revolutions in the 19th century.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][TAB]Another significant revolutionary government was the Soviet Union, established after the communist revolution in Tsarist Russia. The Soviet Union had an explicit goal of world revolution, and actively supported and encouraged communist revolutions across the world. Socialist revolutions have led to the establishment of socialist governments across the globe since then.

[TAB]A constitution is a set of fundamental principles or established precedents according to which a state or other organization is governed. These rules together make up, i.e. constitute, what the entity is. When these principles are written down into a single document or set of legal documents, those documents may be said to embody a written constitution; if they are written down in a single comprehensive document, it is said to embody a codified constitution. Some constitutions (such as the constitution of the United Kingdom) are uncodified, but written in numerous fundamental Acts of a legislature, court cases or treaties.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][TAB]What is sometimes called the "enlightened constitution" model was developed by philosophers of the Age of Enlightenment such as Thomas Hobbes, Jean-Jacques Rousseau, and John Locke. The model proposed that constitutional governments should be stable, adaptable, accountable, open and should represent the people (i.e., support democracy). The United States Constitution, ratified June 21, 1788, was influenced by the writings of Polybius, Locke, Montesquieu, and others. The document became a benchmark for republicanism and codified constitutions written thereafter.

[TAB]A traditionalist society is based on oral traditions and long established ways of doing things. Its authority is difficult to question, since no modern figure can easily claim the right to change what was established by the ancestors. This can be a great weakness of the system when times change, but so long as the basic mechanisms of existence remain stable, the tradition-oriented culture gains a strong sense of its own values, and feels powerful ties to the legacy of its own ancestors. As society became more settled, existing customs grew formalized and expanded. Priests and scribes served as guardians of collective social memory by keeping track of longstanding precedents and rituals, often dating back centuries to quasi-legendary founding heroes. Rulers sought to empower themselves by following the rites and policies established by such traditions.

[TAB]Manorialism was an essential element of feudal society. It was the organizing principle of rural economy that originated in the Roman villa system of the Late Roman Empire, and was widely practiced in medieval western and parts of central Europe. It was slowly replaced by the advent of a money-based market economy and new forms of agrarian contract. Manorialism was characterised by the vesting of legal and economic power in a Lord of the Manor, supported economically from his own direct landholding in a manor (sometimes called a fief), and from the obligatory contributions of a legally subject part of the peasant population under the jurisdiction of himself and his manorial court. These obligations could be payable in several ways, in labor (the French term corvée is conventionally applied), in kind, or, on rare occasions, in coin.

[TAB]Individualism is the moral stance, political philosophy, ideology, or social outlook that emphasizes the moral worth of the individual. Individualists promote the exercise of one's goals and desires and so value independence and self-reliance and advocate that interests of the individual should achieve precedence over the state or a social group, while opposing external interference upon one's own interests by society or institutions such as the government.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][TAB]Liberalism is the belief in the importance of individual freedom. This belief is widely accepted in the United States, Europe, Australia and other Western nations, and was recognized as an important value by many Western philosophers throughout history, in particular since the Enlightenment.

[TAB]While very early societies had a strong state control over the economy, for example in grain storage and distribution, as goods became more complex and trade routes more far reaching, it has become harder for them to exert control over trade. Long distance trade usually took place without state interference by private individuals. For instance, most traders along the silk route organised without any involvement of the involved states. Likewise, states would withdraw from regulating trade and let it pass freely throughout their borders.

[TAB]Regulated Trade describes a government trade policy that seeks to influence foreign trade to the benefit of its national industries. With the Ming dynasty, China started to close off its economy to foreign trade, and likewise Japan forbade interaction with foreign merchants. Besides protecting local craftsmen, this was also meant to keep out dangerous ideas from abroad. In Europe, increasing trade regulation coincided with colonialism. This particular form of regulated trade, Mercantilism, was focused on importing raw goods from the colonies to produce manufactured goods at the exclusion of foreign economies.

[TAB]Free Enterprise (also referred to as Laissez-faire economic policy) is an economic system in which transactions between private parties are free from government intervention such as regulation, privileges, tariffs, and subsidies. The doctrine of laissez-faire became an integral part of nineteenth-century European liberalism. Just as liberals supported freedom of thought in the intellectual sphere, so were they equally prepared to champion the principles of free trade and free competition in the sphere of economics. The state was to be merely a passive policeman, protecting private property and administering justice, but not interfering with the affairs of its citizens. Businessmen, and particularly British industrialists, were quick to associate these principles with their own economic interests.

[TAB]Animism is the religious belief that objects, places, and creatures all possess a distinct spiritual essence. Potentially, animism perceives all things—animals, plants, rocks, rivers, weather systems, human handiwork, and perhaps even words—as animated and alive.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][TAB]Animism is the oldest known type of belief system in the world that even predates paganism. It is still practiced in a variety of forms in many traditional societies. Animism is used in the anthropology of religion as a term for the belief system of many indigenous tribal peoples, especially in contrast to the relatively more recent development of organized religions. Although each culture has its own different mythologies and rituals, "animism" is said to describe the most common, foundational thread of indigenous peoples' "spiritual" or "supernatural" perspectives. The animistic perspective is so widely held and inherent to most animistic indigenous peoples that they often do not even have a word in their languages that corresponds to "animism", or even "religion".

[TAB]Deification (also called Apotheosis) describes raising a human to the status of a God, either posthumously or during their lifetime. These deified rulers used their divine status to cement their authority, and in turn had the duty to secure the support of the gods for their populace. The most well-known examples of deified rulers are the Egyptian pharaohs. Likewise, Chinese emperors justified their rule by having the Mandate of Heaven. Even though the Greco-Roman world had a more republican outlook on government, the Greeks had a tradition of deifying heroes. With the onset of the Roman Empire, emperors were venerated as gods. A similar tradition existed in many Hindu kingdoms in India, Indochina and Indonesia.

[TAB]Clergy refers to a hierarchical and institutional structure within a religion. In particular, the clergy itself is the religious leadership present in various organised religions. The names of members of the clergy vary from religion to religion, but their duties are often similar: interpreting existing religious texts and traditions, resolving open religious questions, and administering the religious organisation itself. Since religion is often an important aspect in the legitimisation of secular power, clergy can often be involved in worldly government or even hold such power itself. The various Christian denominations are the most prominent examples here. The leader of Catholic Christianity, the Pope, once exercised control over much of Italy, and bishops and monastic orders used to rule regions of Europe without any dependence on a higher monarch.

[TAB]Monasticism or monkhood is a religious way of life in which one renounces worldly pursuits to devote oneself fully to spiritual work. Monastic life plays an important role in many Christian churches, especially in the Catholic and Orthodox traditions. Similar forms of religious life also exist in other faiths, most notably in Buddhism, but also in Hinduism and Jainism, although the expressions differ considerably. A religion with focus on monasticism generally is less organised, and concentrated on several monastic orders instead of a central hierarchical order.

[TAB]Tolerance is the acceptance of an action, object, or person which one dislikes or disagrees with, where one is in a position to disallow it but chooses not to. It has also been defined as "to bear or endure" or "to nourish, sustain or preserve" or as "a fair, objective, and permissive attitude toward those whose opinions, beliefs, practices, racial or ethnic origins, etc., differ from one's own; freedom from bigotry" too. Toleration may signify "no more than forbearance and the permission given by the adherents of a dominant religion for other religions to exist, even though the latter are looked on with disapproval as inferior, mistaken, or harmful."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][TAB]There is only one verb to tolerate and one adjective tolerant, but the two nouns tolerance and toleration have evolved slightly different meanings. Tolerance is a state of mind that implies non-judgmental acceptance of different lifestyles or beliefs, whereas toleration indicates the act of putting up with something that one disapproves of. Historically, most incidents and writings pertaining to toleration involve the status of minority and dissenting viewpoints in relation to a dominant state religion.

[TAB]Sovereignty is the full right and power of a governing body over itself, without any interference from outside sources or bodies. A civilisation that has lost the power to assert its own sovereignty has essentially been destroyed or at least subordinated. On the other hand, Sovereignty itself implies that the civilisation exerts no influence over anything else than its core territory.

[TAB]A civilisation that is focused on Conquest perpetuates itself through constant military expansion. This is generally the case for societies that inhabit territory insufficient to support it and that are forced to expand to meet their needs. However, expansionism can also be the cultural norms: societies that value military prowess require constant warfare for new generations of leaders to prove their worth. While such a culture can make a civilisation quite adept at warfare, it also leads to economies that are heavily reliant on the influx of wealth brought about by looting and tribute. In consequence, they are at risk of collapse as soon they suffer their first military setback. This can be seen for example by the rapid military expansion of Alexander's Macedon Empire or the Mongol Empire under the Great Khans.

[TAB]Many Asian civilisations regarded tributary relationships as being more desirable than outright control. Tribute would pacify surrounding powers as well as provide additional income, while requiring no direct military control over defeated enemies. This was especially useful in the relationship with far away powers or those which inhabited rough terrain. Various Chinese dynasties throughout history sought to receive tribute both from the nomads to its north as well as states in South East Asia. The Mongol Empire used the same practice, for example for the fractured states in medieval Russia. In South East Asia, the Mandala system was almost entirely built around tributaries, where important centers such as Ayutthaya, Java or Angkor only kept informal control over their sphere of influence.

[TAB]Isolationist civilisations have deliberately closed themselves off from the outside world. The reasons for doing so can vary. Sometimes, the desire is to exclude outside merchants from competing with the local economy, but another important reason is to keep out foreign ideas and influences that could threaten the existing social order or government. China stopped its naval program during the Ming dynasty and refused requests for foreign trade, considering itself entirely self-sufficient. In Japan during the Tokugawa Shogunate, the introduction of Western technology and Christianity was considered a threat to population's loyalty to the shogun, and the country completely shut itself off from the world. Joseon Korea similarly was known as the Hermit Kingdom.

[TAB]In the early modern era, European naval powers began to discover and colonise various parts of the world, beginning in the Americas, but subsequently also Asia and Africa. While the initial process happened without much direction, colonialism quickly became state policy for these civilisations. Under colonialism, vast amounts of wealth were extracted from colonised regions under the exploitation of their native populations to the benefits of their European homelands. Colonialism led to the displacements of large population groups, especially under the transatlantic slave trade, and introduced new plants and animals to parts of the world that had never seen them before. International prestige was as important to colonialism as its economic benefits, and colonial powers would often get into conflicts over their colonies and involve local neighbours.

[H1]Limited Resource Effects[\H1][NEWLINE]In Dawn of Civilization, the number of cities a resource can provide health or happiness to is limited. For example, each instance of the Silk only provides happiness to three cities in your empire. It is therefore necessary to secure multiple instances of a resource to supply all cities in a large empire. If a civilization does not control enough instances of a resource to supply all of its cities, the effect is applied to more cultured cities first. In consequence, it is advisable for large empires to focus on obtaining multiple instances of the same resource, while small civilizations should focus on a diverse set of resources. Note that these new rules only apply to health or happiness directly from resources. Health and happiness from resources with buildings remain unaffected, as well as all other resource effects (e.g. enabling units or providing power).

[TAB]Temples in ancient Egypt were seen as the houses of gods to whom they were dedicated (or pharaoh whom they commemorated). Their architecture varied a lot over the large time span of Egyptian civilization, from small shrines in the Predynastic Period to the large complexes in the New Kingdom. Their most sacred part of an Egyptian temple was an inner sanctuary that housed the god's image. Access to the sanctuary was typically restricted to the priestly caste, but the rest of the temple was an important place in the daily life of Egyptian commoners. Many temples have survived to the current day and are now touristic assets for modern Egypt, as well as important archaeological sources for Egyptologists.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Les temples de l'Égypte ancienne étaient vus comme les demeures des dieux auxquels ils étaient dédiés (ou des pharaons qu'ils commémoraient). Leur architecture a beaucoup varié à travers la longue histoire de la civilisation égyptienne, des petits lieux de culte de l'époque prédynastique aux grands complexes du Nouvel Empire. La partie la plus sacrée d'un temple égyptien était le sanctuaire. On y conservait une idole du dieu. L'accès au sanctuaire était réservé au clergé, mais le reste du temple n'en constituait pas moins un lieu important dans la vie de la populace égyptienne. De nombreux temples ont survécu et plusieurs sont désormais des attractions touristiques importantes, lorsqu'ils ne jouent pas le rôle de sources archéologiques pour les égyptologues.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Ancestor worship plays a large role in Chinese folk religion, also sometimes called "Shendao" or "Way of the Gods". Temples dedicated to deified ancestors are common, and are closely linked to the emphasis that Chinese culture puts on filial piety. Since Chinese folk religion is complex and diverse, many other types of temples exist in China, including some dedicated to Chinese gods and past emperors. These exist alongside Confucian, Taoist, and Buddhist places of worship.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Le culte des ancêtres joue un large rôle dans la religion traditionnelle chinoise, aussi appelée shenisme. Les temples consacrés aux ancêtres déifiés sont courants et sont à rapprocher de l'importance qu'accorde la culture chinoise à la piété filiale. Étant donné la complexité et la diversité de la religion traditionnelle, de nombreux autres types de temples existent en Chine, comme ceux qui sont dédiés aux dieux et aux empereurs. Ils existent aux côtés de lieux de culte confucéens, taoïstes et bouddhistes.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Vedism refers to the historical religion of the Indo-Aryans of northern India. Descended from proto-Indo-Iranian religion, itself related to proto-Indo-European religion, Vedism may also have been influenced by the religion of the Indus Valley Civilization. At the end of the Vedic period, around 500 BC, Hinduism emerged from Vedism while also diverging significantly from it. Vedism is known primarily through texts rather than archaeology, and therefore knowledge of its places of worship is scant.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Le védisme est la religion historique des Indo-Aryens de l'Inde du Nord. Il descend de la religion proto-indo-iranienne, elle-même apparentée à la religion proto-indo-européenne, mais il pourrait aussi avoir été influencé par la civilisation de la vallée de l'Indus. À la fin de la période védique, vers 500 avant J.-C., l'hindouisme est né du védisme tout en s'en distinguant. Le védisme est connu davantage par des textes que par l'archéologie, aussi sait-on peut de choses quant à ses lieux de culte.

TEXT.English: [TAB]With their colonnades and rectangular floor plans, temples are perhaps the most recognizable form of ancient Greek culture. Built to house the statue of a deity, commonly one of the twelve Olympians, a Greek temple did not typically function as a meeting place. Instead, it was used to store votive offerings, while ceremonies and sacrifices were performed outside. The Greeks exercised a large degree of cultural influence on Rome, who not only adapted many of the Greek gods and deities into their own, but also developed similar temple architecture. As a result of Greco-Roman influence, columned temples have been built widely across Europe, North Africa and the Middle East. Two of the best known examples are the Parthenon in Athens and the Pantheon in Rome, both of which were later converted to churches, a fate that befell many other Greco-Roman temples.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Avec leurs colonnades et leur configuration rectangulaire, les temples sont peut-être la composante la plus typique de la culture grecque ancienne. Un temple grec était bâti pour loger la statue d'une divinité, souvent l'un des douze dieux olympiens. Il ne servait généralement pas de lieu de réunion; on y entreposait plutôt des offres votives, tandis que les cérémonies et les sacrifices avaient lieu dehors. Les Grecs ont exercé une grande influence culturelle sur Rome, qui a non seulement adapté les dieux grecs pour en faire les leurs, mais aussi développé une architecture religieuse similaire. Étant donné l'influence gréco-romaine sur le monde méditerranéen, des temples à colonnes ont été construits dans une grande partie de l'Europe, de l'Afrique du Nord et du Moyen-Orient. Deux des exemples les plus connus sont le Parthénon à Athènes et le Panthéon à Rome, tous deux convertis en églises à l'ère chrétienne. De nombreux autres temples gréco-romains ont subi le même sort.

TEXT.English: [TAB]In the ancient Levant, "Baal" was a title meaning "lord" and was given to several gods of the Ancient Canaanite religion. For instance, the main god of the city of Carthage was Baal Hammon. Details of Phoenician religious organization and buildings are scarce, although it is known that Carthage had a well-organized caste of priests. The city was also reported by several Roman writers as having practiced child sacrifice for Baal Hammon, but the issue is still contentious among historians due to the poorness of archeological sources and the partisan nature of the literary ones.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Dans le Proche-Orient ancien, le mot "Baal" était un titre honorifique signifiant "seigneur", mais prenant aussi un sens religieux lorsqu'il était donné aux dieux de la religion cananéenne et phénicienne. Par exemple, le dieu principal de Carthage était Baal Hammon. Peu de détails sont connus au sujet de la religion phénicienne. On sait toutefois que les Carthaginois avaient une caste de prêtre bien organisée. De nombreux auteurs romains ont affirmé que la cité pratiquait le sacrifice d'enfants pour Baal Hammon, mais la pauvreté des sources archéologiques et la nature partisane des sources littéraires ne permettent pas de trancher.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Atua are the gods and spirits of the Polynesians. Across the Pacific Ocean, Polynesian religious activity mostly took place at communal areas called mala'e or marae. In Hawaii, native temples are known as "heiau" and were built for a variety of deities and purposes.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Les atua sont les dieux et les esprits des peuples polynésiens. À travers l'océan Pacifique, l'activité religieuse se concentrait dans des lieux publics appelés mala'e ou marae. À Hawaï, les temples des indigènes sont appelés "heiau" et furent construits pour toutes sortes de divinités et d'usages.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Mazdaism, named for its central deity Ahura Mazda, refers to the religion of the Iranian people prior to the reforms of Zoroaster. Mazdaism is thought to have resembled Vedism, the ancient religion of India, but little information about it is available, including anything about its places of worship.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Le mazdéisme, nommé d'après sa divinité centrale Ahura Mazda, est la religion du peuple iranien avant les réformes de Zoroastre. On pense que le mazdéisme ressemblait au védisme, la religion de l'Inde antique, mais les sources sur le sujet sont rares, y compris quant aux lieux de culte.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The various civilizations of Mesoamerica were the most prolific builders of step pyramids. Such constructions typically included a temple at the top, and were in many cases periodically expanded in a layerwise fashion. Step pyramids exist in a diversity of architectural styles, but common elements show the cultural influence that the Mesoamerican peoples had on one another. Notable examples include the Templo Mayor of Tenochtitlan, the Pyramids of the Sun and of the Moon in Teotihuacan, the Temple of Kukulkan in Chichen Itza, and the Great Pyramid of Cholula, which is the largest pyramid known to exist in the world.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Les civilisations de la Mésoamérique précolombienne furent de grands bâtisseurs de pyramides à degrés. Ces constructions étaient généralement dotées d'un temple à leur sommet, et étaient dans plusieurs cas agrandies périodiquement en ajoutant des couches. Si les pyramides mésoaméricaines présentent une grande diversité styles architecturaux, elles comportent aussi des éléments communs qui témoignent de l'influence culturelle que les peuples exerçaient les uns sur les autres. Citons en exemple le Templo Mayor de Tenochtitlan, les Pyramides du Soleil et de la Lune de Teotihuacan, la Pyramide de Kukulcán à Chichén Itzá, ainsi que la Grande Pyramide de Cholula, qui est la pyramide la plus volumineuse du monde.

TEXT.English: [TAB]In Shinto, shrines are places of worship that house one or more kami, a concept that can be translated as "spirit" or "essence". Many Shinto shrines have a torii, a traditional gate that marks the transition between the mundane and the sacred. Estimates put the number of Shinto shrines in Japan around 100,000. With its "floating" torii, Itsukushima Shrine is perhaps the most well-known.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Dans le shintoïsme, un sanctuaire est un lieu de culte où l'on vénère un (ou plusieurs) kami, soit une divinité, un esprit ou un élément de la nature. De nombreux sanctuaires shinto comportent un portail traditionnel appelé torii. Le torii marque la transition entre le monde profane et l'enceinte sacrée. Il existerait environ 100 000 sanctuaires shinto au Japon. Le plus célèbre d'entre eux, avec son torii "flottant", est sans doute celui d'Itsukushima.

TEXT.English: [TAB]In ancient Norse religion, rites were performed both in the outdoors and at temples called hofs. The most famous hof in the Middle Ages was the temple at Old Uppsala, Sweden, and was described by the 11th century chronicler Adam of Bremen as being made of gold and containing statues of Thor, Odin, and Freyr. With the revival of Norse paganism under the name "Asatru", some modern buildings have been dedicated as hofs, and a new pagan temple is under construction in Iceland as of 2018.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Dans la religion nordique ancienne, les rites avaient lieu à la fois en plein air et au sein de temples appelés en vieux norrois "hofs". Le hof le plus célèbre du Moyen Âge était le temple d'Uppsala, en Suède, décrit par le chroniqueur du 11e siècle Adam de Brême comme paré d'or et renfermant les statues de Thor, d'Odin et de Freyr. Depuis la résurgence du paganisme nordique sous le nom d'"Ásatrú", certains bâtiments modernes se sont vus consacrés comme hofs, et un nouveau temple païen est en construction en Islande en 2018.

TEXT.English: [TAB]A nemeton is a sacred place of the ancient Celtic religion. Nemeta are typically thought of as outdoor spaces in which druids would perform ceremonies. However, there is evidence that nemeta took a variety of forms, including ritual enclosures, shrines, and temples. Several toponyms in modern Europe derive from the word "nemeton".
TEXT.French: [TAB]Un nemeton est un lieu sacré de la religion celte ancienne. Les nemetons sont généralement perçus comme des espaces en plein air où les druides dirigeaient des cérémonies. Toutefois, il pouvait s'agir d'enclos rituels, de sanctuaires ou de temples. Le mot "nemeton" a survécu dans la toponymie de nombreux lieux européens.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Perun, whose main attributes are thunder and lightning, is the highest god of Slavic polytheism. The most important shrine dedicated to Perun was found on the peninsula of Peryn, near the city of Veliky Novgorod, which was an major religious center in the Early Middle Ages. Various other temples of Slavic paganism existed, but most were destroyed and replaced by churches during the Christianization of the Slavs.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Péroun, dont les attributs principaux sont la foudre et le tonnerre, est le dieu prédominant du polythéisme slave. Le sanctuaire le plus important qui lui est consacré se trouve sur la péninsule de Peryn, près de Novgorod, qui fut un centre religieux d'importance durant le haut Moyen Âge. De nombreux autres temples païens ont existé, mais ils furent en général détruits et remplacés par des églises au moment de la christianisation des Slaves.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Traditional African religions are highly diverse. The religious tradition of the Yoruba people, originally from Nigeria and the surrounding countries, has spread around the world due to the Atlantic slave trade. Its sacred places include the cities of Ife and Oyo, and the grove of Osun-Osogbo.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Il existe une grande diversité de religions traditionnelles africaines. Celle du peuple yoruba, originaire du Nigeria et des pays environnants, s'est propagée à travers le monde via le commerce transatlantique des esclaves. Ses lieux sacrés comprennent les villes d'Ife et d'Oyo ainsi que la forêt d'Osun-Osogbo.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Among the deities worshipped by the Inca, the sun god, Inti, was arguably the most prominent. Each major province of the Inca Empire had a temple dedicated to Inti. The most important one was Coricancha, meaning "gold enclosure". True to its name, it was opulently decorated with gold until the Spanish conquerors pillaged and destroyed it. Its foundations still exist beneath the Santo Domingo convent in Cuzco.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Parmi les divinités vénérées par les Incas, le dieu-soleil Inti est possiblement le plus important. Chaque province de l'Empire inca était dotée d'un temple dédié à Inti. Le plus sacré était le Coricancha, dont le nom signifie "enceinte de l'or". Richement paré d'or, il fut pillé et détruit par les conquistadors espagnols. Ses fondations existent encore sous le couvent Santo Domingo à Cuzco.

TEXT.English: [TAB]An obo, also spelled ovoo or oboo, is a stone and wood heap used as an altar or shrine in Mongolian shamanism, which is part of the larger Tengrist religious tradition. Obos are often found in high places such as mountaintops. While they can be very simple, some have evolved to become elaborate structures akin to temples.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Un ovoo, ou obo, est un amas de pierre et de bois utilisé comme autel ou comme sanctuaire par les adeptes du chamanisme mongol, qui est l'une des manifestations du tengrisme. Les ovoos sont souvent construits en hauteur, par exemple au sommet des montagnes. Certains sont devenus des structures élaborées comparables à des temples.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Hubal was an important god worshipped in Arabia in pre-Islamic times. Hubal's consort was Manat, one of the three main goddesses of Arabian polytheistic religion. The Kaaba, in Mecca, later to become the holiest site in Islam, was initially a shrine dedicated to Hubal and contained an idol of the god, among others.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Houbal était un dieu important de l'Arabie préislamique. Il était lié à Manât, l'une des trois grandes déesses du polythéisme arabe. À La Mecque, la Kaaba, qui deviendrait plus tard le lieu le plus sacré de l'Islam, était à l'origine un sanctuaire dédié notamment à Houbal, dont elle renfermait une idole.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Before the spread of Christianity to Ethiopia in the 4th century, religion in the Aksumite Empire was closely related to the Semitic polytheism of Southern Arabia. It has been suggested that its principal god was Astar, a male deity equivalent to Mesopotamian goddess Ishtar.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Avant l'arrivée du christianisme en Éthiopie, au 4e siècle, la religion de l'Empire aksoumite était proche du polythéisme sémitique d'Arabie méridionale. Sa divinité principale pourrait avoir été Astar, un équivalent masculin de la déesse mésopotamienne Ishtar.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Mugyo ("Religion of the Mu (shamans)"), also known as Sinism, Shenism, or Shindo, is the Korean folk religion or Korean shamanism. Central to Korean shamanism is the belief in many different gods, supernatural beings and ancestor worship. The mu are described as chosen persons. Historically, Korean shamanism and traditional religion relied upon a system of ancestral shrines, Sadang, similar to those found in China and Japan. Larger temples are called myo (literally "temple") or gung (literally "palace"). Korean shamanic temples may be distinguished by their use of taegeuk and manja symbolism, and some of them have gates similar to Japanese Shinto torii.

[TAB]A man of war is an armed naval vessel. The term often refers to ship armed with cannon and propelled primarily by sails as opposed to a galley propelled primarily by oars. The man of war was developed in the Mediterranean in the 15th century from earlier roundships with the addition of a second mast to form the carrack. The 16th century saw the carrack evolve into the galleon and then the ship of the line.[PARAGRAPH:1]A first-rate man of war, such as the HMS Victory was armed with 100 or more guns (as many as 120). The 90-gun HMS Coronation was a second-rate man of war. A seventy-four, a common ship carrying 74 guns, was a third-rate man of war. A sixth-rate man of war carried only 20 guns. First and second-rate men of war had three gun decks. It took over 2,000 oak and elm trees to build a second-rate man of war.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The bandeirantes (Portuguese: "Followers of the banner") were composed of Indians (slaves and allies), caboclos (people of Indian mixed with white), and whites who were the captains of the Bandeiras. Members of the 16th-18th century South American slave-hunting expeditions called bandeiras (Portuguese for "flags"). Though their original purpose was to capture and force amerindians into slavery, the bandeirantes later began to focus their expeditions on finding gold, silver and diamond mines. They ventured into unmapped regions in search of profit and adventure. From 1580-1670 the Bandeirantes focused on slave hunting, then from 1670-1750 they focused on mineral wealth. Through these expeditions, the Bandeirantes also expanded Portuguese America from the small limits of the Tordesilhas Line to roughly the same territory as current Brazil. This expansion discovered mineral wealth that made the fortune of Portugal during the 17th and 18th centuries.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Prussia made early use of the title "fusilier" for various types of infantry. In 1705, the Foot Guards (Leibgarde zu Fuss) were designated as Fusilier Guards. By 1837, low-quality infantry raised from garrison companies also were named fusiliers. These latter units were dressed in blue with low mitre caps. Between 1740 and 1743 on Frederick the Great raised 14 separate Fusilier Regiments (numbers 33-40, 41-43 and 45-48). Except for the mitre caps, these new regiments were identical in appearance, training and role to the existing line infantry (musketeers).[PARAGRAPH:2]Subsequently, Prussia and several other German states used the designation Fusilier to denote a type of light infantry, dressed in green, that acted as skirmishers. In the Prussian Army, they had been formed in 1787 as independent battalions, with many of the Officers having had experience in the American Revolutionary War. The Prussian reforms of 1808 absorbed the fusiliers as the third battalion of each line infantry regiment. Now wearing the same Prussian blue uniforms as standard musketeers, they were distinguished by black leather belts, and a slightly different arrangement of cartridge pouch.[PARAGRAPH:2]In the Prussian Army of 1870, Infantry Regiments 33 to 40 plus Regiments 73 (Hanover), 80 (Hesse-Kassel or Hesse-Cassel) and 86 (Schleswig-Holstein) were all designated as fusiliers, as was the Guard Fusilier Regiment. In addition, the third battalions of all guard, grenadier and line infantry regiments retained the designation 'Fusilier Battalion'. They were armed with a slightly shorter version of the Dreyse rifle (Füsiliergewehr), that took a sword bayonet (Füsilier-Seitengewehr) rather than the standard socket bayonet. Although still theoretically skirmishers, in practice they differed little from their compatriots, as all Prussian infantry fought in a style that formed a dense 'firing' or 'skirmish' line.

TEXT.English: [TAB]A llanero (plainsman) is a Venezuelan or Colombian herder. The name is taken from the Llanos grasslands occupying western Venezuela and eastern Colombia. The Llanero were originally part Spanish and Indian and have a strong culture including a distinctive form of music.[PARAGRAPH:1]During the wars of independence, Llaneros served in both armies and provided the bulk of the cavalry during the war. In 1819, an army of Llaneros, led by Simón Bolívar and José Antonio Páez, defeated the Spanish with a surprise attack when they crossed over the Orinoco plains and the Andes mountains.

TEXT.English: [TAB]American pioneers are any of the people in American history who migrated west to join in settling and developing new areas. The term especially refers to those who were going to settle any territory which had previously not been settled or developed by European, African or American society, although the territory was inhabited by or utilized by Native Americans.[PARAGRAPH:2]The pioneer concept and ethos greatly predate the migration to parts of the United States now called Western, as many places now considered as East were also settled by pioneers from the coast. For example, Daniel Boone, a key figure in American history, settled in Kentucky, when that "Dark and Bloody Ground" was still undeveloped.[PARAGRAPH:2]One important development in the Western settlement was the Homestead Act, which provided formal legislation for the settlers which regulated the settlement process.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Tercio ("one third"), also known as Tercio Español, was a Renaissance era military formation similar to and derivative of the Swiss pike square and was a term used to describe a mixed infantry formation of about 3,000 pikemen, swordsmen and arquebusiers in a mutually supportive formation; it was also sometimes referred to by other nations as a Spanish Square after its introduction by the Spanish army, and was widely adopted across international lines and dominated formalized field warfare for more than a century.[PARAGRAPH:1]The Tercio Español was the product of the Italian Wars in which the Spanish general, Gonzalo Fernández de Córdoba, would reorganize the Spanish army throughout a series of conflicts at the end of the 15th and early 16th centuries, into a tactically unique combination of modern and medieval combined arms centered around armored infantry. This emphasis on the infantry was the result of Spain's great dependence on mules in daily life, which in turn resulted in an inability to raise large cavalry forces. It marked the transformation of medieval military institutions into the early modern combined-arms army. Gonzalo Fernández, developed the Tercio to further increase the effectiveness of Spanish infantry against every manner of opposing infantry while remaining impervious to the dangers of a cavalry charge.[PARAGRAPH:1]At first the army consisted of units of around 6000 men, called coronelias, which by 1534 had been reduced into the Tercios of 3000 for increased mobility on the offensive.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Artificial satellites are spacecraft that maintain an orbit around a celestial body. What differentiates an orbit from other types of space flight is it doesn't require any additional propulsion. Satellites can hold a number of different orbits. One type is a polar orbit, which causes the spacecraft to pass over the north and south poles. Another is an equatorial orbit, which causes the satellite to circle the Earth's equator. The farther the orbit from the surface of the earth, the longer it takes to complete a circuit of the earth. If the vessel uses an equatorial orbit at a distance of 22,300 miles from Earth, it can achieve geo-synchronous orbit, which causes the satellite to remain stationary over a specific area.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Les satellites artificiels sont des engins spatiaux en orbite autour d'un corps céleste. Ce qui différencie une orbite d'un autre type de vol spatial est qu'elle n'implique pas l'utilisation d'un système de propulsion. Il existe de nombreuses orbites différentes. Il y a ainsi l'orbite polaire : l'engin spatial passe au-dessus des pôles nord et sud. Il existe aussi l'orbite équatoriale : le satellite longe l'Equateur. Plus l'orbite est éloignée de la surface de la Terre, plus l'engin mettra de temps pour faire le tour de la planète. Un engin en orbite équatoriale à 36 000 Km de la Terre peut effectuer une orbite géosynchrone, c'est-à-dire qu'il reste stationnaire au-dessus d'une zone spécifique.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Künstliche Satelliten sind unbemannte Raumflugkörper, die in der Umlaufbahn eines Planeten kreisen. Die orbitale Raumfahrt unterscheidet sich von der herkömmlichen Raumfahrt vor allem dadurch, dass kein zusätzliches Antriebssystem vorhanden sein muss. Satelliten können eine Reihe von Orbitalbahnen einschlagen, so zum Beispiel einen Polarorbit, der den Raumflugkörper über den Nord- und den Südpol steuert. Eine weitere Orbitalbahn ist der Äquatorialorbit, wobei der Satellit entlang des Erdäquators kreist. Je weiter die Umlaufbahn von der Erdoberfläche entfernt ist, desto länger dauert die vollständige Umkreisung der Erde. Wenn der Raumflugkörper im Äquatorialorbit eine Entfernung von etwa 36.000 Kilometern von der Erde erreicht, tritt er in die geostationäre Umlaufbahn ein, wodurch sich der Satellit dauerhaft nur noch innerhalb eines bestimmten Bereichs fortbewegt.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]I satelliti artificiali sono navicelle spaziali che mantengono un'orbita attorno a un corpo celeste. Ciò che differenzia un'orbita dagli altri tipi di volo spaziale è la mancanza del requisito di propulsione da parte della prima. I satelliti possono avere più orbite diverse: un tipo è quella polare, che fa passare la navicella attraverso il Polo Nord e il Polo Sud; un altro tipo è l'orbita equatoriale, che fa passare il satellite lungo l'equatore terrestre. Più lontana è l'orbita dalla superficie della Terra, più tempo occorre per completare il giro del pianeta. Se il satellite segue un'orbita equatoriale alla distanza di 36.000 Km dalla Terra, entra in un'orbita geostazionaria, il che significa che esso rimane stazionario sopra un'area specifica del globo.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]Los satélites artificiales son naves espaciales que mantienen una órbita alrededor de un cuerpo celeste. Lo que diferencia una órbita de otras clases de vuelo espacial es que no requiere propulsión adicional. Los satélites pueden describir distintos tipos de órbitas. Una de ellas es la órbita polar, que hace que la nave sobrevuele los polos norte y sur. Otra es la órbita ecuatorial, que hace que el satélite rodee la Tierra por el ecuador. Cuanto más alejada esté la órbita de la superficie de la tierra, más tiempo tarda en completar una circunferencia alrededor del planeta. Si la nave emplea una órbita ecuatorial a una distancia de 35.890 km de la Tierra, puede alcanzar la órbita geosíncrona, lo que hace que el satélite permanezca fijo sobre un área específica.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The earliest military forces were simply the citizens of the city, armed with whatever implements they could use as weapons. Although a militia made up of warriors was inexpensive, they were no match for organized armies. Warriors were usually used as stopgap measures while waiting for superior units to be trained, or to defend a city that had been temporarily cut off from military support. In a crisis situation, an assembly of warriors is better than no defense at all.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Les premières forces militaires étaient simplement composées des habitants des villes, équipés de tout ce qui pouvait faire office d'arme. Si ces milices composées de guerriers n'étaient pas onéreuses, elles ne pouvaient en revanche pas rivaliser avec des armées organisées. Les guerriers étaient surtout utilisés comme solution provisoire en attendant que soient entraînées des troupes plus puissantes, ou servaient à défendre les villes qui se retrouvaient temporairement sans soutien militaire. En situation de crise, un groupe de guerriers est toujours mieux que rien du tout.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Die frühen militärischen Streitkräfte bestanden schlicht aus den Bürgern einer Stadt, die sich mit allem rüsteten, was annähernd als Waffe benutzt werden konnte. Zwar waren aus Kriegern bestehende Kampftruppen preiswert im Unterhalt, dennoch konnten sie natürlich nicht mit organisierten militärischen Truppenverbänden konkurrieren. Dementsprechend wurden die Krieger gewöhnlich als Notlösung eingesetzt, um die Wartezeit bis zur Vollendung der Ausbildung fortgeschrittener Einheiten zu überbrücken oder um Städte zu verteidigen, die auf das Eintreffen militärischer Unterstützung warteten. Fest steht allerdings, dass ein einfacher Kriegertrupp in einer Krisensituation immer noch besser ist als gar keine Verteidigung.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]I primi eserciti della storia erano formati dagli abitanti delle città equipaggiati di qualsiasi cosa potesse considerarsi un'arma. Malgrado una milizia formata da guerrieri occasionali non costasse nulla, questa non poteva affrontare eserciti organizzati. I guerrieri venivano di norma utilizzati come soluzione provvisoria, in attesa dell'addestramento di unità più qualificate o per difendere una città tagliata fuori dai rifornimenti militari. In situazioni di crisi, era meglio avere un manipolo di guerrieri in difesa piuttosto che nulla.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]Las primeras fuerzas militares no eran más que los habitantes de la ciudad, armados con las herramientas que pudieran emplear como armas. Aunque una milicia compuesta de guerreros no suponía muchos gastos, no eran rivales para los ejércitos organizados. Los guerreros se empleaban normalmente como algo provisional mientras se esperaba a tener entrenadas unidades superiores, o para defender una ciudad a la que se le había cortado el suministro militar temporalmente. En situaciones de crisis, una congregación de guerreros es mejor que no tener nada.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The sword developed from the dagger when the construction of longer blades became possible, from the late 3rd millennium BC in the Middle East, first in arsenic copper, then in tin-bronze. The oldest sword-like weapons are found at Arslantepe, Turkey, and date to around 3300 BC. However, it is generally considered that these are longer daggers, and not the first ancestors of swords. Sword blades longer than 60 cm (24 in) were rare and not practical until the late Bronze Age because the tensile strength of bronze is relatively low, and consequently longer blades would bend easily.

TEXT.English: [TAB]One of the most important developments in the history of warfare was the invention of firearms. Originally developed in the 14th century, firearms evolved quickly, and by the late 17th century flintlock muskets had become commonplace in battle. Musketmen, who were relatively inexpensive to equip and train, proved a deadly foe for the knights who had dominated the battlefield for so many years. Armies were often comprised of a combination of musketmen, cannon, and knights, each complementing the strengths and weaknesses of the others. Large forces of musketmen within a fortress or behind city walls proved an exceedingly difficult obstacle to an attacking army. Muskets were the primary firearms in use until they were replaced by repeating rifles in the mid-19th century.
TEXT.French: [TAB]L'invention des armes à feu fut l'une des évolutions les plus importantes de l'histoire de la guerre. Créées au XIVe siècle, celles-ci évoluèrent rapidement, et à la fin du XVIIe siècle, l'utilisation de mousquets à silex sur les champs de bataille s'était généralisée. Les arquebusiers coûtaient peu à former et à équiper, et étaient redoutablement efficaces face aux chevaliers, qui avaient pourtant dominé les champs de bataille pendant des siècles. Les armées étaient souvent composées d'arquebusiers, de canons et de chevaliers, et chacun de ces éléments compensait les faiblesses des autres. De plus, une forteresse ou une ville fortifiée défendue par un grand nombre d'arquebusiers devenait pratiquement inexpugnable. Les mousquets furent les principales armes à feu jusqu'à leur remplacement par les fusils à répétition, au milieu du XIXe siècle.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Eine der historisch wichtigsten kriegstechnischen Erfindungen waren Feuerwaffen. Die im 14. Jahrhundert begonnene Entwiclung schritt rasch voran, und im späten 17. Jahrhundert war der Einsatz von Steinschlossmusketen im Gefecht alltäglich geworden. Die Ausbildung und Ausrüstung der Musketiere war vergleichsweise kostengünstig und sie erwiesen sich für die Ritter, die so viele Jahre lang das Kampfgeschehen dominiert hatten, als tögliche Gegner. Häufig wurden Musketiere, Kanonen und Ritter, deren Stärken und Schwächen sich gut ergänzten, in einem Truppenverband zusammengeschlossen. Größere Musketiertruppen in einer Festung oder hinter Stadtmauern Posten stellten für angreifende Streitmächte ein nahezu unüberwindbares Hindernis dar. Lange Zeit waren Musketen die vorherrschenden Schusswaffen auf dem Schlachtfeld, bis sie Mitte des 19. Jahrhunderts von den Repetiergewehren abgelöst wurden.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]Uno dei più importanti sviluppi nella storia bellica fu l'invenzione delle armi da fuoco. Originariamente sviluppate nel quattordicesimo secolo, le armi da fuoco progredirono rapidamente e verso la fine del diciassettesimo secolo i moschetti con otturatore a pietra focaia erano ormai comuni sul campo di battaglia. I moschettieri, che erano relativamente economici da equipaggiare e da addestrare, si rivelarono un nemico micidiale per i cavalieri, che avevano dominato il campo di battaglia per così tanti anni. Gli eserciti comprendevano spesso una parte di moschettieri, cannoni e cavalieri, ciascuno dei quali compensava i punti di forza e di debolezza degli altri. Le ampie formazioni di moschettieri all'interno di una fortezza o dietro le mura della città si rivelarono un ostacolo estremamente ostico per un esercito all'assalto. I moschetti erano la principale arma da fuoco in uso, fino a quando non furono sostituiti dai fucili a ripetizione, alla metà del diciannovesimo secolo.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]La invención de las armas de fuego fue uno de los descubrimientos más importantes en la historia de la guerra. Desarrolladas originalmente en el siglo XIV, las armas de fuego evolucionaron con rapidez, y a finales del siglo XVII, los mosquetes de chispa eran habituales en la batalla. Los soldados con mosquete, que eran relativamente baratos de equipar y entrenar, resultaron ser un enemigo mortal para los caballeros, que habían dominado el campo de batalla durante tantos años. Los ejércitos estaban a menudo compuestos por una combinación de mosqueteros, cañones y caballeros, cada uno complementando los puntos fuertes y débiles de los otros. Las fortalezas y las murallas, defendidas por grandes contingentes de soldados con mosquete, eran un tremendo obstáculo para los ejércitos atacantes. Los mosquetes fueron las armas principales de fuego hasta que fueron sustituidos por los rifles de repetición a mediados del siglo XIX.

TEXT.English: [TAB]An unmanned combat aerial vehicle (UCAV), also known as a combat drone or simply a drone, is an unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) that usually carries aircraft ordnance such as missiles and is used for drone strikes. These drones are usually under real-time human control, with varying levels of autonomy. Aircraft of this type have no onboard human pilot. As the operator runs the vehicle from a remote terminal, equipment necessary for a human pilot are not needed, resulting in a lower weight and a smaller size than a manned aircraft. China, Israel, and the United States are widely recognized as industry leaders in UCAV technology. Several other countries have operational domestic UCAVs and many more have imported armed drones or have development programs under way.

TEXT.English: [TAB]A steamship, often referred to as a steamer, is a type of steam powered vessel, typically ocean-faring and seaworthy, that is propelled by one or more steam engines that typically move (turn) propellers or paddlewheels. The first steamships came into practical usage during the early 1800s; however, there were exceptions that came before. Steamships usually use the prefix designations of "PS" for paddle steamer or "SS" for screw steamer (using a propeller or screw). As paddle steamers became less common, "SS" is assumed by many to stand for "steam ship". Ships powered by internal combustion engines use a prefix such as "MV" for motor vessel, so it is not correct to use "SS" for most modern vessels.[PARAGRAPH:2]As steamships were less dependent on wind patterns, new trade routes opened up. The steamship has been described as a "major driver of the first wave of trade globalization (1870–1913)" and contributor to "an increase in international trade that was unprecedented in human history".[PARAGRAPH:2]The steamship was preceded by smaller vessels designed for insular transportation, called steamboats. Once the technology of steam was mastered at this level, steam engines were mounted on larger, and eventually, ocean-going vessels. Becoming reliable, and propelled by screw rather than paddlewheels, the technology changed the design of ships for faster, more economic propulsion.[PARAGRAPH:2]Paddlewheels as the main motive source became standard on these early vessels. It was an effective means of propulsion under ideal conditions but otherwise had serious drawbacks. The paddle-wheel performed best when it operated at a certain depth, however when the depth of the ship changed from added weight it further submerged the paddle wheel causing a substantial decrease in performance.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Broadly speaking, spears were either designed to be used in melee, or to be thrown. Within this simple classification, there was a remarkable range of types. For example, M.J. Swanton identified thirty different spearhead categories and sub-categories in Early Saxon England. Most medieval spearheads were generally leaf-shaped. Notable types of Early medieval spears include the angon, a throwing spear with a long head similar to the Roman pilum, used by the Franks and Anglo-Saxons, and the winged (or lugged) spear, which had two prominent wings at the base of the spearhead, either to prevent the spear penetrating too far into an enemy or to aid in spear fencing. Originally a Frankish weapon, the winged spear also was popular with the Vikings. It would become the ancestor of later medieval polearms, such as the partisan and spetum.[PARAGRAPH:2]The thrusting spear also has the advantage of reach, being considerably longer than other weapon types. Exact spear lengths are hard to deduce as few spear shafts survive archaeologically but 6–8 ft (1.8–2.4 m) would seem to have been the norm. Some nations were noted for their long spears, including the Scots and the Flemish. Spears usually were used in tightly ordered formations, such as the shieldwall or the schiltron. To resist cavalry, spear shafts could be planted against the ground. William Wallace drew up his schiltrons in a circle at the Battle of Falkirk in 1298 to deter charging cavalry, it was a widespread tactic sometimes known as the "crown" formation.[PARAGRAPH:2]Throwing spears became rarer as the Middle Ages drew on, but survived in the hands of specialists such as the Catalan Almogavars. They were commonly used in Ireland until the end of the 16th century.[PARAGRAPH:2]Spears began to lose fashion among the infantry during the 14th century, being replaced by pole weapons that combined the thrusting properties of the spear with the cutting properties of the axe, such as the halberd. Where spears were retained they grew in length, eventually evolving into pikes, which would be a dominant infantry weapon in the 16th and 17th centuries.

Notable types of Early medieval spears include the angon, a throwing spear with a long head similar to the Roman pilum, used by the Franks and Anglo-Saxons, and the winged (or lugged) spear, which had two prominent wings at the base of the spearhead, either to prevent the spear penetrating too far into an enemy or to aid in spear fencing. Originally a Frankish weapon, the winged spear also was popular with the Vikings. It would become the ancestor of later medieval polearms, such as the partisan and spetum.[PARAGRAPH:2]The thrusting spear also has the advantage of reach, being considerably longer than other weapon types. Exact spear lengths are hard to deduce as few spear shafts survive archaeologically but 6–8 ft (1.8–2.4 m) would seem to have been the norm. Some nations were noted for their long spears, including the Scots and the Flemish. Spears usually were used in tightly ordered formations, such as the shieldwall or the schiltron. To resist cavalry, spear shafts could be planted against the ground. William Wallace drew up his schiltrons in a circle at the Battle of Falkirk in 1298 to deter charging cavalry, it was a widespread tactic sometimes known as the "crown" formation.[PARAGRAPH:2]Throwing spears became rarer as the Middle Ages drew on, but survived in the hands of specialists such as the Catalan Almogavars. They were commonly used in Ireland until the end of the 16th century.[PARAGRAPH:2]Spears began to lose fashion among the infantry during the 14th century, being replaced by pole weapons that combined the thrusting properties of the spear with the cutting properties of the axe, such as the halberd. Where spears were retained they grew in length, eventually evolving into pikes, which would be a dominant infantry weapon in the 16th and 17th centuries.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Automation is the technology by which a process or procedure is performed with minimal human assistance. Automation or automatic control is the use of various control systems for operating equipment such as machinery, processes in factories, boilers and heat treating ovens, switching on telephone networks, steering and stabilization of ships, aircraft and other applications and vehicles with minimal or reduced human intervention.[PARAGRAPH:2]Automation covers applications ranging from a household thermostat controlling a boiler, to a large industrial control system with ten of thousands of input measurements and output control signals. In control complexity, it can range from simple on-off control to multi-variable high-level algorithms.[PARAGRAPH:2]In the simplest type of an automatic control loop, a controller compares a measured value of a process with a desired set value, and processes the resulting error signal to change some input to the process, in such a way that the process stays at its set point despite disturbances. This closed-loop control is an application of negative feedback to a system. The mathematical basis of control theory was begun in the 18th century and advanced rapidly in the 20th.[PARAGRAPH:2]Automation has been achieved by various means including mechanical, hydraulic, pneumatic, electrical, electronic devices and computers, usually in combination. Complicated systems, such as modern factories, airplanes and ships typically use all these combined techniques. The benefit of automation includes labor savings, savings in electricity costs, savings in material costs, and improvements to quality, accuracy, and precision.[PARAGRAPH:2]The term automation, inspired by the earlier word automatic (coming from automaton), was not widely used before 1947, when Ford established an automation department. It was during this time that industry was rapidly adopting feedback controllers, which were introduced in the 1930s.

TEXT.English: [TAB]A container port or container terminal is a facility where cargo containers are transshipped between different transport vehicles, for onward transportation. The transshipment may be between container ships and land vehicles, for example trains or trucks, in which case the terminal is described as a maritime container port. Alternatively the transshipment may be between land vehicles, typically between train and truck, in which case the terminal is described as an inland container port.[PARAGRAPH:2]In November 1932, the first inland container port in the world was opened by the Pennsylvania Railroad company in Enola, Pennsylvania. Port Newark-Elizabeth on the Newark Bay in the Port of New York and New Jersey is considered the world's first maritime container port. On April 26, 1956, the Ideal X was rigged for an experiment to use standardized cargo containers that were stacked and then unloaded to a compatible truck chassis at Port Newark. The concept had been developed by the McLean Trucking Company. On August 15, 1962, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey opened the world's first container port, Elizabeth Marine Terminal.
